abstract: In this article, the 2010 European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) recommendations for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with synthetic and biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (sDMARDs and bDMARDs, respectively) are updated. The 2013 update was developed by an international working group, which based its decisions mostly on evidence from three systematic reviews of the literature (one each on sDMARDs, including glucocorticoids, bDMARDs and safety aspects of treatment with DMARDs); The searches also covered treatment strategies. The evidence presented was discussed and summarized by experts in the course of a consensus-building and voting process. Levels of evidence and scores of recommendations were extracted and levels of agreement (strengths of recommendations) were determined. Fourteen recommendations were developed (instead of 15 recommendations in 2010). Some of the 2010 recommendations were deleted, others were modified or divided. The recommendations cover general aspects, such as achieving remission or reduced disease activity using a treatment-to-target approach, and the need for shared decision-making between rheumatologists and patients. The most specific items relate to initiating DMARD treatment with a conventional sDMARD strategy (csDMARD) in combination with glucocorticoids, followed by the addition of a bDMARD or another csDMARD strategy (after stratification by presence or absence of adverse risk factors) if the treatment goal is not reached within 6 months. (Or no improvement is observed within 3 months). The tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (adalimumab, certolizumab pegol, etanercept, golemumab, infliximab, biosimilars), abatacept, tocilizumab, and, under certain conditions, rituximab, are considered to have similar efficacy and safety. If the first bDMARD strategy fails, any other bDMARD strategy may be used. The recommendations also address tofacitinib as a targeted sDMARD (tsDMARD), which, where licensed, is recommended after at least one bDMARD. Biosimilars are also being addressed. These recommendations are intended to inform rheumatologists, patients, national rheumatology societies, and other stakeholders about the latest EULAR consensus on the management of rheumatoid arthritis with sDMARDs, glucocorticoids, and bDMARDs. It is based on evidence and expert opinion and aims to improve outcomes in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

abstract: Conventional nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are associated with a range of toxic effects, particularly gastrointestinal (GI) effects, due to inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX)-1. It is not known whether specific COX-2 inhibitors are associated with fewer GI toxic effects. To determine whether celecoxib, a specific COX-2 inhibitor, is associated with a lower incidence of major upper GI toxic effects and other adverse effects compared with conventional NSAIDs. The Celecoxib Long-Term Arthritis Safety Study (CLASS), a randomized, double-blind trial conducted from September 1998 to March 2000. Three hundred eighty-six clinical sites in the United States and Canada. A total of 8059 patients (>/= 18 years) with osteoarthritis (OA) or rheumatoid arthritis (RA) were enrolled in the study, and 7968 of them received at least one dose of the study drug. A total of 4573 patients (57%) received treatment for 6 months. Patients were randomly assigned to receive celecoxib, 400 mg twice daily (2 and 4 times the maximum doses for RA and OA, respectively; n = 3987); Ibuprofen, 800 mg 3 times daily (n = 1985); or diclofenac, 75 mg twice daily (n=1,996). The use of aspirin for cardiovascular disease prevention (<=325 mg/day) has been permitted. Occurrence of future upper gastrointestinal ulcer symptoms, ulcer complications (bleeding, perforation, and obstruction) and other adverse effects during the 6-month treatment period. For all patients, the annual incidence rates of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications alone and combined with a symptomatic ulcer for celecoxib versus NSAIDs were 0.76% versus 1.45% (P = 0.09) and 2.08% versus 3.54% (P = 0.02). respectively. For patients not taking aspirin, the annual incidence rates of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications alone and with a symptomatic ulcer for celecoxib versus NSAIDs were 0.44% versus 1.27% (P = 0.04) and 1.40% versus 2.91% (P = 0.02). For patients taking aspirin, the annual incidence rates of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications alone and with a symptomatic ulcer for celecoxib versus NSAIDs were 2.01% versus 2.12% (P = 0.92) and 4.70% versus 6.00% (P = 0.49). Fewer patients treated with celecoxib than patients treated with NSAIDs developed chronic GI blood loss, GI intolerance, hepatotoxicity, or nephrotoxicity. No difference in the incidence of cardiovascular events was observed between celecoxib and NSAIDs, regardless of aspirin use. In this study, celecoxib, at doses greater than those clinically indicated, was associated with a lower incidence of symptomatic ulcers and combined ulcer complications, as well as other clinically important toxic effects, compared with NSAIDs at standard doses. The reduction in upper GI toxicity was stronger among patients not taking aspirin concomitantly. Gamma. 2000;284:1247-1255

abstract: Prostaglandin (PG)E2 is a powerful mediator of pain and inflammation, and high levels of this lipid mediator have been observed in many pathological conditions. Inhibiting PGE2 production to control pain and treat diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis has so far relied on NSAIDs such as aspirin. However, these agents inhibit the synthesis of all prostanoids. To produce biologically active PGE2, PGE enzymes catalyze the isomerization of PGH2 to PGE2. Recently, several PGEs have been identified and cloned, but their role in inflammation is unclear. To study the physiological role of individual PGEs, we generated by targeted homologous recombination a mouse line deficient in microsomal PGE synthase 1 (mPGES1) on an inbred DBA/1lacJ background. mPGES1-deficient (mPGES1-/-) mice are viable, fertile, and develop normally compared to wild-type controls. However, mPGES1−/− mice showed significantly reduced inflammatory responses compared with mPGES1+/+ mice in multiple assays. Here, we identify mPGES1 as a PGE synthase that contributes to the pathogenesis of collagen-induced arthritis, a disease model of human rheumatoid arthritis. We also show that mPGES1 is responsible for the production of PGE2 that mediates acute pain during the inflammatory response. These results suggest that mPGES1 provides a target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases and pain associated with inflammatory conditions.

abstract: To investigate the efficacy and safety of SC-58635 (celecoxib), an anti-inflammatory and analgesic agent that acts by selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibition and is not expected to cause typical gastrointestinal (GI), renal, and platelet-related symptoms. Side effects associated with COX-1 enzyme inhibition. Four phase II trials were conducted: a 2-week osteoporosis efficacy trial, a 4-week rheumatoid arthritis efficacy trial, a 1-week endoscopic study of gastrointestinal mucosal effects, and a 1-week study of effects on platelet function. Both arthritis trials determined dose levels of SC-58635 that were consistently effective in treating signs and symptoms of arthritis and were distinct from placebo on standard arthritis measures. In the upper gastrointestinal endoscopy study, 19% of people receiving naproxen (6 of 32) developed gastric ulcers, while no ulcers occurred in people receiving SC-58635 or placebo. A study of platelet effects revealed no significant effect of SC-58635 on platelet aggregation or thromboxane B2 levels, whereas aspirin caused a significant decrease in 2 of 3 measures of platelet aggregation and thromboxane B2 levels. In all four trials, SC-58635 was well tolerated, with a safety profile similar to that of placebo. SC-58635 achieves analgesic and anti-inflammatory efficacy in arthritis through selective COX-2 inhibition, showing no evidence of the 2 toxic effects of COX-1 inhibition associated with NSAIDs.

abstract: Acid suppression with famotidine, a histamine H2 receptor antagonist, provides protection against gastric injury in normal subjects receiving short courses of aspirin or naproxen. The effectiveness of famotidine in preventing peptic ulcers in patients receiving long-term treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is unknown. We studied the effectiveness of two doses of famotidine (20 mg and 40 mg, each given orally twice daily), compared with placebo, in preventing peptic ulcers in 285 patients without peptic ulcers who were receiving long-term treatment with NSAIDs. Steroids for rheumatoid arthritis (82 percent) or osteoporosis (18 percent). Patients were evaluated clinically and endoscopically at baseline and after 4, 12, and 24 weeks of treatment. The residents were not aware of the treatment assignment. The primary endpoint was the cumulative incidence of gastric or duodenal ulceration at 24 weeks. The cumulative incidence of stomach ulcers was 20 percent in the placebo group, 13 percent in the group of patients receiving 20 mg of famotidine twice daily (P = 0.24 for comparison with placebo), and 8 percent in the group receiving famotidine 40 mg. Twice daily (P = 0.03 for comparison with placebo). The proportion of patients who developed a duodenal ulcer was significantly lower with both doses of famotidine than with placebo (13 percent in the placebo group, 4 percent in the low-dose famotidine group [P = 0.04], and 2 percent in the placebo group). P = 0.01]). Both doses of famotidine were well tolerated. Treatment with high-dose famotidine significantly reduces the cumulative incidence of both gastric and duodenal ulcers in patients with arthritis receiving long-term NSAID therapy.

abstract: Vitamin K antagonists are highly effective in preventing stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation but have several limitations. Apixaban is a new oral direct factor Xa inhibitor that has been shown to reduce the risk of stroke in a similar population compared to aspirin. In this randomized, double-blind trial, we compared apixaban (at a dose of 5 mg twice daily) with warfarin (target international normalized ratio, 2.0 to 3.0) in 18,201 patients with atrial fibrillation and at least one additional risk factor for stroke. The primary outcome was ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke or systemic embolism. The trial was designed to test non-inferiority, with the main secondary objectives of testing superiority with respect to the primary outcome and rates of major bleeding and death from any cause. The average duration of follow-up was 1.8 years. The rate of the primary outcome was 1.27% per year in the apixaban group, compared with 1.60% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio with apixaban, 0.79; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.66 to 0.95; P<0.001) for noninferiority; P = 0.01 for superiority). The rate of major bleeding was 2.13% per year in the apixaban group, compared with 3.09% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.69; 95% CI, 0.60 to 0.80; P < 0.001), and the rates of death. for any cause were 3.52% and 3.94%, respectively (hazard ratio, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.80 to 0.99; P=0.047). The rate of hemorrhagic stroke was 0.24% per year in the apixaban group, compared with 0.47% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.51; 95% CI, 0.35 to 0.75; P < 0.001), and the rate of hemorrhagic stroke or uncertain type of stroke was 0.97% per year in the apixaban group and 1.05% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.74 to 1.13; P = 0.42). In patients with atrial fibrillation, apixaban was superior to warfarin in preventing stroke or systemic embolism, caused less bleeding, and resulted in lower mortality. (Funded by Bristol-Myers Squibb and Pfizer; ARISTOTLE ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00412984.).

abstract: Despite current treatments, patients with acute coronary syndromes without ST-segment elevation have high rates of major vascular events. We evaluated the efficacy and safety of the antiplatelet agent clopidogrel when administered with aspirin in these patients. We randomly assigned 12,562 patients who presented with symptoms within 24 hours after symptom onset to receive clopidogrel (300 mg immediately, followed by 75 mg once daily) (6,259 patients) or placebo (6,303 patients) plus aspirin for 3 to 12 months. . . The first primary outcome—cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or stroke—occurred in 9.3% of patients in the clopidogrel group and 11.4% of patients in the placebo group (relative risk with clopidogrel Compared to patients who took clopidogrel). with placebo, 0.80, 95 percent confidence interval, 0.72 to 0.90; The second primary outcome—the first primary outcome or refractory ischemia—occurred in 16.5 percent of patients in the clopidogrel group and 18.8 percent of patients in the placebo group (relative risk, 0.86; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.79 to 0.94). . ; p < 0.001). The percentages of patients with in-hospital acute or refractory ischemia, heart failure, and revascularization procedures were also significantly lower with clopidogrel. There were significantly more patients with major bleeding in the clopidogrel group than in the placebo group (3.7 percent versus 2.7 percent; relative risk, 1.38; P = 0.001), but there were not significantly more patients with of life-threatening bleeding episodes (2.2 percent [corrected] vs. 1.8 percent; P=0.13) or hemorrhagic strokes (0.1 percent vs. 0.1 percent). The antiplatelet agent clopidogrel has beneficial effects in patients with acute coronary syndromes without ST-segment elevation. However, the risk of major bleeding is increased among patients treated with clopidogrel.

abstract: To determine the effects of antiplatelet therapy among patients at high risk for vaso-occlusive events. Collaborative meta-analyses (methodological overviews). Randomized trials of one antiplatelet regimen versus control or of one antiplatelet regimen versus another in high-risk patients (with acute or preexisting vascular disease or some other predisposing condition) for which results were available before September 1997. The trials had to use a randomization method that precluded knowledge prior to the next treatment to be assigned, and comparisons should be unlinked – that is, study groups that differ only in terms of their antiplatelet regimen. 287 studies included 135,000 patients in comparisons of antiplatelet therapy versus control and 77,000 in comparisons of different antiplatelet regimens. “Severe vascular event”: non-fatal myocardial infarction, non-fatal stroke, or vascular death. Overall, among these high-risk patients, allocation to antiplatelet therapy reduced the pooled score for any major vascular event by approximately one-quarter; Non-fatal myocardial infarction was reduced by a third, non-fatal stroke by a quarter, and vascular deaths by a sixth (with no apparent negative effect on other deaths). The absolute reductions in risk of a serious vascular event were 36 (SE 5) per 1000 person-years treated among patients with a previous myocardial infarction; 38 (5) per 1000 patients treated for 1 month among patients with acute myocardial infarction; 36 (6) per 1000 treated for 2 years among those with previous stroke or transient ischemic attack; 9 (3) per 1,000 people treated for three weeks among people with acute stroke; and 22 (3) per 1,000 treated for 2 years among other high-risk patients (with results separately significant for those with stable angina (P = 0.0005), peripheral arterial disease (P = 0.004), and atrial fibrillation (P = 0.01 )). In each of these high-risk categories, the absolute benefits greatly outweigh the absolute risks of major extracranial hemorrhage. Aspirin has been the most extensively studied antiplatelet drug, with doses of 75 to 150 mg daily at least as effective as higher daily doses. The effects of doses lower than 75 mg daily have been less certain. Clopidogrel reduced serious vascular events by 10% (4%) compared with aspirin, which was similar to the 12% (7%) reduction observed with its counterpart ticlopidine. Adding dipyridamole to aspirin did not result in a significant reduction in vascular events compared with aspirin alone. Among patients at high risk for immediate coronary occlusion, short-term addition of a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa antagonist to aspirin prevented 20 (4) additional vascular events per 1,000 (P < 0.0001) but caused 23 major (but rare) bleeding often fatal) outside the skull per 1,000. Aspirin (or another oral antiplatelet drug) is prophylactic in most types of patients at increased risk of vaso-occlusive events, including those with acute myocardial infarction or ischemic stroke, Or unstable or stable angina, previous myocardial infarction, stroke or cerebral ischemia. - Peripheral arterial disease, or atrial fibrillation. Low dose aspirin (75-150 mg daily) is an effective antiplatelet regimen for long-term use, but in severe cases an initial loading dose of at least 150 mg aspirin may be required. Adding a second antiplatelet drug to aspirin may provide additional benefits in some clinical situations, but more research into this strategy is needed.

abstract: Several clinical trials have evaluated the benefit of long-term use of antiplatelet drugs in reducing the risk of clinical thrombotic events. Aspirin and ticlopidine have been shown to be effective, but both have serious potential adverse effects. Clopidogrel, a new thienopyridine derivative similar to ticlopidine, is an inhibitor of adenosine diphosphate-induced platelet aggregation. The CAPRIE trial was an international, randomized, blinded trial designed to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of clopidogrel (75 mg once daily) and aspirin (325 mg once daily) in reducing the risk of a composite outcome group of stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. ; Their relative safety was also evaluated. The population studied consisted of subgroups of patients with atherosclerotic vascular disease manifesting as either recent ischemic stroke, recent myocardial infarction, or symptomatic peripheral arterial disease. Patients were followed for 1 to 3 years. 19,185 patients were recruited, with more than 6,300 patients in each clinical subgroup, over 3 years, with a mean follow-up of 1.91 years. There were 1,960 primary events included in the outcome set, with intention-to-treat analysis showing that patients treated with clopidogrel had a 5.32% annual risk of ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death compared with 5.83% with aspirin. These rates reflect a statistically significant (p = 0.043) reduction in relative risk of 8.7% in favor of clopidogrel (95% Cl 0.3-16.5). The corresponding on-treatment analysis yielded a relative risk reduction of 9.4%. There were no significant differences in terms of safety. Adverse experiences reported in the clopidogrel and aspirin groups were judged to be severe rash (0.26% vs. 0.10%), diarrhea (0.23% vs. 0.11%), upper GI discomfort (0.97% vs. 1.22%), and bleeding. intracranial (0.33% vs. 0.47). %), and gastrointestinal bleeding (0.52% vs. 0.72%), respectively. There were ten (0.10%) patients in the clopidogrel group with a significant decrease in neutrophils (<1.2 × 10(9)/L) and 16 (0.17%) in the aspirin group. Long-term administration of clopidogrel to patients with atherosclerotic vascular disease is more effective than aspirin in reducing the risk of stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. The overall safety of clopidogrel is at least as good as that of moderate-dose aspirin.

abstract: Throughout the usual LDL cholesterol range in Western populations, lower blood concentrations are associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Therefore, in such populations, reducing LDL cholesterol may reduce the development of vascular disease, largely independent of initial cholesterol concentrations. 20,536 UK adults (aged 40-80 years) with coronary artery disease, other arterial-occlusive disease or diabetes were randomly allocated to receive simvastatin 40 mg daily (median compliance: 85%) or placebo Matched (average statin use without study: 17%). ). Analyzes are first performed for specific events, comparing all participants assigned to simvastatin versus all participants assigned to placebo. These “intention-to-treat” comparisons evaluate the effects of about two-thirds (85% minus 17%) taking a statin during the scheduled 5-year treatment period, which resulted in a mean difference in low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (About two-thirds of the effect of actual use of 40 mg of simvastatin daily). Primary outcomes were mortality (for overall analyses) and fatal or nonfatal vascular events (for subgroup analyses), with subcategories for cancer and other major morbidity. All-cause mortality was significantly reduced (1,328 [12.9%] deaths among 10,269 simvastatin assigned vs. 1,507 [14.7%] among 10,267 placebo assigned; P = 0.0003), due to a very significant relative reduction of 18%. (SE 5) in coronary mortality (587 [5.7%] vs. 707 [6.9%]; P = 0.0005), and a marginally significant reduction in other vascular deaths (194 [1.9%] vs. 230 [2.2%]; P = 0.07), and a non-significant reduction in non-vascular mortality (547 [5.3%] versus 570 [5.6%]; P = 0.4). There were highly significant reductions of about a quarter in the first event rate for nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death (898 [8.7%] versus 1212 [11.8%]; P < 0.0001), for nonfatal or fatal stroke (444 [4.3%]). vs 585 [5.7%]; p<0.0001), and for coronary or non-coronary revascularization (939 [9.1%] vs 1205 [11.7%]; p<0.0001). For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events, there was a significant 24% (SE 3; 95% CI 19-28) reduction in event rate (2033 [19.8%] versus 2585 [25.2%] of affected individuals; p < 0.0001 ). During the first year, the reduction in major vascular events was not significant, but was subsequently very large during each separate year. The relative reduction in event rate was similar (and significant) in every subgroup of participants studied, including: those who were not diagnosed with coronary artery disease and who had cerebrovascular disease, had peripheral artery disease, or They had diabetes; Men and women separately; Those aged 70 or over at entry; And - especially - even those with LDL cholesterol less than 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL), or total cholesterol less than 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). The benefits of simvastatin were additional to those of other cardiac treatments. The excess annual risk of myopathy with this regimen was approximately 0.01%. There were no significant adverse effects on cancer incidence or on hospitalization for any reason other than vascular. Adding simvastatin to existing therapies safely results in significant additional benefits for a wide range of high-risk patients, regardless of their initial cholesterol concentrations. An assignment of 40 mg of simvastatin daily reduced the rates of myocardial infarction, stroke, and revascularization by about a quarter. After accounting for non-compliance, actual use of this system would likely reduce these rates by about a third. Hence, among the many types of high-risk individuals studied, taking simvastatin for 5 years would prevent about 70-100 people per 1000 from suffering at least one of these major vascular events (and longer treatment should to more benefits). The magnitude of the 5-year benefit is based primarily on these individuals' overall risk of major vascular events, not on blood lipid concentrations alone.

abstract: Statin treatment reduces low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels and the risk of cardiovascular disease, but it is not known whether the addition of ezetimibe, a non-statin drug that reduces intestinal cholesterol absorption, can further reduce the rate of cardiovascular events. We conducted a randomized, double-blind trial that included 18,144 patients who were hospitalized for acute coronary syndrome within the previous 10 days and had LDL cholesterol levels of 50 to 100 mg per deciliter (1.3 to 2.6 mmol per liter) if they were receiving treatment. Lipid-lowering therapy or 50 to 125 mg per deciliter (1.3 to 3.2 mmol per liter) if they are not receiving lipid-lowering therapy. The combination of simvastatin (40 mg) and ezetimibe (10 mg) (simvastatin-ezetimibe) was compared with simvastatin (40 mg) and placebo (simvastatin monotherapy). The primary endpoint was a composite of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, unstable angina requiring rehospitalization, coronary revascularization (≥30 days after randomization), or nonfatal stroke. . The average follow-up was 6 years. The average LDL cholesterol level during the study was 53.7 mg per deciliter (1.4 mmol per liter) in the simvastatin-ezetimibe group, compared with 69.5 mg per deciliter (1.8 mmol per liter) in the simvastatin monotherapy group (1.8 mmol per liter). p < 0.001). The Kaplan-Meier event rate for the primary endpoint at 7 years was 32.7% in the simvastatin-ezetimibe group, compared with 34.7% in the simvastatin monotherapy group (absolute risk difference, 2.0 percentage points; hazard ratio, 0.936; 95). % confidence interval, 0.89 to 0.99; P = 0.016). Rates of prespecified muscle, gallbladder, and hepatic adverse effects and cancer were similar in the two groups. When added to statin therapy, ezetimibe resulted in a gradual reduction in LDL cholesterol levels and improved cardiovascular outcomes. Furthermore, lowering LDL cholesterol to levels below previous targets provides an additional benefit. (Funded by Merck; IMPROVE-IT ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00202878.).

abstract: Individuals with diabetes are at increased risk of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, even though plasma LDL cholesterol concentrations are similar to those in the general population. Previous evidence about the effects of cholesterol-lowering in people with diabetes has been limited, and most people with diabetes are not currently receiving cholesterol-lowering treatment despite their increased risk. 5,963 UK adults (aged 40-80 years) known to have diabetes, plus a further 14,573 with atherosclerotic disease (but no diagnosed diabetes), were randomly allocated to receive 40 mg of simvastatin daily Or a matching placebo. Prespecified analyzes were in these prior disease subcategories, and other relevant subcategories, for first major coronary event (ie, nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death) and first major vascular event (ie, major coronary event, stroke, or revascularization) . Analyzes of subsequent vascular events during the scheduled treatment period were also performed. Comparisons were made between all participants assigned to simvastatin versus all participants assigned to placebo (i.e., intention-to-treat), resulting in a mean difference in low-density lipoprotein cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (39 mg/dL) during The treatment period is 5 years. Both among participants who developed diabetes and among those who did not, there were very large reductions of about a quarter in the first event rate of major coronary events, strokes, and revascularization. For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events among participants with diabetes, there was a significant 22% (95% CI 13-30) reduction in event rate (601 [20.2%] simvastatin assigned versus 748 [25.1%]) assigned to treatment. placebo, P < 0.0001), which was similar to that found among other high-risk individuals studied. There were also very significant reductions of 33% (95% CI 17-46, p = 0.0003) among the 2,912 diabetic participants who had no occlusive arterial disease diagnosed at entry, and 27% (95% CI 13-40, p = 0.0003). p=0.0007) among 2426 diabetic participants whose pre-treatment LDL cholesterol concentration was <3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL). The relative risk reduction was also about one-quarter among various other subgroups of diabetes patients studied, including: those with different duration, type, or control of diabetes; People over 65 years of age at admission or with high blood pressure; and those with total cholesterol less than 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). In addition, among participants who had their first major vascular event after randomization, simvastatin assignment reduced the rate of subsequent events during the scheduled treatment period. The current study provides direct evidence that cholesterol-lowering therapy is beneficial for people with diabetes even if they do not already have obvious coronary disease or high cholesterol concentrations. An assignment of 40 mg of simvastatin daily reduced the rate of first major vascular events by about a quarter in the broad group of diabetic patients studied. After accounting for noncompliance, actual use of this statin regimen would reduce these rates by about a third. For example, among diabetics studied without obstructive arterial disease, 5-year treatment is expected to prevent about 45 people per 1,000 from having at least one major vascular event (and of those 45 people, about 70 first prevent )or subsequent events during this treatment period). Statin therapy should now be considered routinely for all diabetic patients at high enough risk for major vascular events, regardless of their initial cholesterol concentrations.

abstract: In patients with existing cardiovascular disease, residual cardiovascular risk persists despite achieving target low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels with statin therapy. It is not clear whether extended-release niacin added to simvastatin to raise low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol is superior to simvastatin alone in reducing this residual risk. We randomly assigned eligible patients to receive extended-release niacin, 1500 to 2000 mg daily, or matching placebo. All patients received simvastatin, 40 to 80 mg per day, plus ezetimibe, 10 mg per day, if necessary, to maintain an LDL cholesterol level of 40 to 80 mg per deciliter (1.03 to 2.07 mmol per liter). The primary endpoint was the first event of death from coronary heart disease, nonfatal myocardial infarction, ischemic stroke, hospitalization for acute coronary syndrome, or symptomatic coronary or cerebral revascularization. A total of 3414 patients were randomly assigned to receive niacin (1718) or placebo (1696). The trial was stopped after a median follow-up period of 3 years due to ineffectiveness. After two years, treatment with niacin significantly increased the average HDL cholesterol level from 35 mg per deciliter (0.91 mmol per liter) to 42 mg per deciliter (1.08 mmol per liter), and reduced the triglyceride level from 164 mg per deciliter ( 1.85 mmol per liter). L) to 122 mg per deciliter (1.38 mmol per liter), and reduced the level of harmful cholesterol from 74 mg per deciliter (1.91 mmol per liter) to 62 mg per deciliter (1.60 mmol per liter). The primary endpoint occurred in 282 patients in the niacin group (16.4%) and in 274 patients in the placebo group (16.2%) (hazard ratio, 1.02; 95% confidence interval, 0.87 to 1.21; P = 0.79 by log-rank test). Among patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and LDL cholesterol levels less than 70 mg per deciliter (1.81 mmol per liter), there was no increased clinical benefit from adding niacin to statin therapy over a 36-month follow-up period, although Great importance. Improvements in HDL cholesterol and triglyceride levels. (Funded by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute and Abbott Laboratories; AIM-HIGH ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00120289.).

abstract: It has been consistently found that lower blood cholesterol concentrations are closely associated with a lower risk of coronary heart disease but not with a lower risk of stroke. Despite this observation, previous randomized trials have suggested that cholesterol-lowering statin therapy reduces the risk of stroke, but large-scale prospective confirmation is needed. 3,280 adults with cerebrovascular disease, 17,256 adults with other arterial occlusive diseases or diabetes, or a matching placebo were randomly assigned to simvastatin 40 mg daily. Subgroup analyzes were prespecified for the first “major vascular event” (i.e., nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death, stroke of any type, or any revascularization procedure) in prior disease subcategories. Sub-outcomes included any stroke and stroke subtype. Comparisons were made between all participants assigned to simvastatin versus all participants assigned to placebo (i.e., “intention to treat”), which resulted in a mean difference in low-density lipoprotein cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (39 mg/dL) during the treatment period. Which lasted 5 years. a period. Overall, there was a highly significant relative reduction of 25% (95% CI 15-34) in the rate of first stroke event (444 [4.3%] simvastatin vs. 585 [5.7%] placebo; P < 0.0001), reflecting Specific outcome 28 percent (19-37) reduction in presumed ischemic strokes (p<0.0001) and no clear difference in strokes attributed to hemorrhage (51 [0.5%] vs. 53 [0.5%]; rate ratio 0.95 [-0.65]. 1.40]; p=0.8). In addition, simvastatin reduced the numbers of people with transient ischemic attacks alone (2.0% vs. 2.4%; P = 0.02) or requiring carotid endarterectomy or angioplasty (0.4% vs. 0.8%; P = 0.0003). The reduction in stroke was not significant during the first year, but was already significant (P = 0.0004) by the end of the second year. Among patients with pre-existing cerebrovascular disease, there was no clear reduction in the rate of stroke, but there was a very significant 20% (8-29) reduction in the rate of any major vascular event (406 [24.7%] vs. 488 [29.8%]; p = 0.001). The relative reductions in stroke were about a quarter in each of the other subgroups of study participants, including: those with coronary artery disease or diabetes; Those aged 70 or over at entry; and those with different levels of blood pressure or lipids (even when pre-treatment LDL cholesterol was less than 3.0 mmol/L [116 mg/dL]). Far more people in this study had a stroke than in any previous cholesterol-lowering trial. The results showed that statin therapy rapidly reduces the incidence not only of coronary events but also of ischemic strokes, with no apparent effect on cerebral hemorrhage, even among individuals without high cholesterol concentrations. An assignment of 40 mg of simvastatin daily reduced the stroke rate by about a quarter, and so, after accounting for noncompliance in the trial, actual use of this regimen would likely reduce the stroke rate by about a third. The HPS also provides conclusive evidence that statin treatment is beneficial for people with pre-existing cerebrovascular disease, even if they do not already have obvious coronary disease.

abstract: Previous studies have shown that experimental hypercholesterolemia leads to vasodilation of the coronary artery (VV) vasculature. Recent evidence suggests that HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors (statins) have beneficial effects independent of lipid lowering. We aimed to determine the effect of simvastatin on VV coronary angiogenesis, in the absence of cholesterol lowering. Pigs were randomized into 3 groups fed a normal (N), high-cholesterol (HC), or HC + simvastatin (HC + S) diet for 12 weeks. The proximal left anterior descending artery was isolated, examined by micro-CT, and reconstructed. Quantification of VV density was then performed in serial cross-sections along the vessel. LDL cholesterol was similarly increased in HC and HC+S compared with N. There was an increase in VV density (4.7 +/- 0.3 vs. 2.7 +/- 0.2 N/mm(2); P < 0.05) and vessel wall area. (3.1 +/- 0.2 vs. 1.8 +/- 0.1 mm(2); P < 0.05) in HC compared to N. VV density was preserved in HC + S compared to HC (3.0 +/- 0.2 N/mm(2) ) ; P < 0.05), despite a similar increase in vessel wall area compared with N (2.5 +/- 0.1 mm(2); P < 0.05). Coronary tissue expression of VEGF was increased in HC but not in HC + S compared with N. In parallel, immunoreactivity of HIF-1alpha, VEGF, MMP-2, and MMP-9 in exogenous media was highlighted in HC but not in HC + S compared With N. This study demonstrates that simvastatin attenuates coronary and VV wall hypoxia in experimental hypercholesterolemia, although there is no change in plasma lipids. These data are consistent with an additional mechanism for the vascular effects of statins, independent of cholesterol lowering.

abstract: Simvastatin attenuates ischemia and reperfusion in animals with normal cholesterol levels by stabilizing endothelial nitric oxide synthase activity and inhibiting neutrophil-mediated injury. Since endothelial dysfunction is a deleterious effect of hypercholesterolemia, we examined whether short-term treatment with simvastatin could prevent leukocyte-endothelium interaction and attenuate myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury in apoE-deficient (apoE(-/-)) mice. )) which feeds on a high percentage of cholesterol. Diet. We studied leukocyte-endothelium interactions in apoE(−/−) mice fed a normal diet or a high-cholesterol diet after short-term (i.e., 18 h) simvastatin treatment. We also examined simvastatin treatment in myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury by subjecting apoE(−/−) mice to 30 min of ischemia and 24 h of reperfusion. ApoE(-/-) mice fed a high-cholesterol diet showed higher serum cholesterol levels, which were not affected by short-term treatment with simvastatin. However, the increased leukocyte rolling and adherence that occurred in cholesterol-fed apoE(−/−) mice ( P < 0.001 vs. control diet) was significantly attenuated by simvastatin treatment ( P < 0.01 vs. vehicle). Cholesterol-fed apoE(-/-) mice exposed to myocardial ischemia and reperfusion also had increased myocardial necrosis ( P < 0.01 vs. control diet), which was significantly attenuated by simvastatin ( P < 0.01 vs. vehicle). Simvastatin treatment also significantly increased vascular nitric oxide production in apoE(−/−) mice. Simvastatin attenuates leukocyte-endothelial cell interactions and attenuates ischemic injury in hypercholesterolemic mice independently of lipid-lowering actions.

abstract: From a physiological perspective, physical activity is expected to reduce the risk of stroke. However, epidemiological studies of physical activity and stroke risk have yielded mixed results. We therefore sought to examine the relationship between exercise and stroke risk. This was a prospective cohort study of 21,823 men, who were followed for an average of 11.1 years. Participants were from the Physicians' Health Study, a randomized trial of low-dose aspirin and beta-carotene. The men, aged 40 to 84 years at baseline, were free of self-reported myocardial infarction, stroke, transient ischemic attacks, and cancer. Basically, they reported repeating exercise vigorous enough to induce a sweat. The occurrence of stroke was self-reported by participants and confirmed after review of medical records (n=533). We used Cox proportional hazards regression to analyze the data. With adjustment for age, treatment assignment, smoking, alcohol intake, history of angina, and parental history of myocardial infarction, the relative risks of total stroke associated with vigorous exercise were <1 time, 1 time, 2 to 4 times, and >/= 5 Times per week at baseline were 1.00 (reference), 0.79 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.61 to 1.03), 0.80 (95% CI, 0.65 to 0.99), and 0.79 (95% CI, 0.61 to 1.03), respectively; P for trend = 0.04. In subgroup analyses, the inverse association appeared stronger for hemorrhagic stroke than for ischemic stroke. When we also adjusted for body mass index, history of hypertension, high cholesterol, and diabetes, the corresponding relative risks for total stroke were 1.00 (reference), 0.81 (95% CI, 0.61 to 1.07), 0.88 (95% CI, 0.70). ) to 1.10), and 0.86 (95% CI, 0.65 to 1.13), respectively; F for trend = 0.25. Exercise vigorous enough to induce perspiration is associated with a lower risk of stroke in men. In this study, the inverse association with physical activity appears to be through beneficial effects on body weight, blood pressure, blood cholesterol, and glucose tolerance. Aside from its positive effects on these variables, physical activity had no significant residual association with stroke incidence.

abstract: The beneficial effects of statins in preventing cardiovascular disease may depend, at least in part, on their anti-inflammatory effect. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of simvastatin and aspirin on serum levels of C-reactive protein (CRP), tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha), and interleukin 6 (IL-6) in subjects with hypercholesterolemia. In 33 asymptomatic men with total cholesterol (TC) > 6.5 mmol L(-1) and in 25 men with coronary heart disease and borderline high cholesterol levels (between 5.2 and 6.5 mmol L(-1)) treated chronically with a low dose... Determination of aspirin (75 mg/day), CRP, TNF-alpha, IL-6, and IL-8 levels in the blood before and after treatment with simvastatin for 3 months (20-40 mg daily). In the first group, these inflammatory markers were also measured before and after a two-week treatment with aspirin (300 mg/day), which was carried out before and in combination with simvastatin. A clear decrease in CRP and TNF-alpha was found in both groups; IL-6 levels decreased only in people with marked hypercholesterolemia. Aspirin had no effect on the anti-inflammatory action of simvastatin. In men with hypercholesterolemia, simvastatin treatment reduces levels of CRP and proinflammatory cytokines in the blood. Low dose aspirin does not add to the anti-inflammatory action of simvastatin.

abstract: Previous studies of diet and coronary heart disease (CHD) have focused on the intake of nutrients rather than whole foods. Because of findings that dietary fiber, folic acid, and antioxidants may be protective for coronary heart disease, increasing vegetable intake has been recommended. However, due to the chemical and physical complexity of vegetables, the effects of individual nutrients may vary if eaten as whole foods. Furthermore, little is known about the direct relationship between vegetable intake and the risk of coronary heart disease. We prospectively evaluated the association between vegetable intake and risk of coronary heart disease in the Physicians' Health Study, a randomized trial of aspirin and beta-carotene among 22,071 US physicians aged 40–84 years in 1982. In this analysis, we included 15,220 men without or without heart disease. Stroke or cancer at baseline who provided information on their vegetable intake at baseline and at years 2, 4 and 6 of follow-up using a simple semi-quantitative food frequency questionnaire including eight vegetables. We confirmed 1148 cases of coronary heart disease (387 myocardial infarction and 761 incident cases of coronary artery bypass grafting or percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty) during 12 years of follow-up. After adjusting for age, randomized treatment, body mass index (BMI), smoking, alcohol intake, physical activity, history of diabetes, history of high blood pressure, history of high cholesterol, and multivitamin use, men who took at least 2.5 serving/day of vegetables had a relative risk (RR) of 0.77 (95% CI: 0.60-0.98) for developing coronary heart disease, compared with men in the lowest category (<1 serving/day). By adjusting for the same covariates in the trend analysis that considered vegetable intake as a continuous variable, we found an RR of 0.83 (95% CI: 0.71-0.98) for the risk of coronary heart disease per additional serving/day of vegetables. The inverse association between vegetable intake and risk of coronary heart disease was more pronounced among men with a BMI > or = 25 (RR = 0.71, 95% CI: 0.51-0.99) or current smokers (RR = 0.40, 95% CI: 0.18). -0.86) compared to the highest and lowest intake categories. Our results indicate an inverse relationship between vegetable intake and the risk of coronary heart disease. These prospective data support current dietary guidelines for increasing vegetable intake to prevent coronary heart disease.

abstract: Homeless people represent a highly disadvantaged group in North America. Among older homeless men, cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death. The aim of this study was to examine cardiovascular risk factors in a representative sample of homeless adults and to identify opportunities to improve risk factor modification. Homeless persons were randomly assigned to shelters for single adults in Toronto. The response rate was 79%. Participants (n = 202) underwent interviews, physical measurements, and blood sampling. The average age of participants was 42 years, and 89% of them were men. The prevalence of smoking among homeless persons (78%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 72% to 84%) was significantly higher than in the general population (standardized morbidity ratio [SMR], 254; 95% CI, 216 to 297). High blood pressure, high cholesterol, and diabetes were no more prevalent than in the general population but were often poorly controlled. Homeless men were significantly less likely to be overweight or obese than men in the general population (SMR, 79; 95% CI, 63 to 98). Past-year cocaine use was reported by 29% of subjects (95% CI, 23% to 36%). Cardiovascular disease was reported by 15% of subjects, and less than a third reported taking aspirin or cholesterol-lowering medications. According to multiple risk factor equations, the estimated median absolute 10-year risk of myocardial infarction or coronary death among homeless men aged 30 to 74 years was 5% (interquartile range, 3% to 9%). Cardiovascular risk factor modification is suboptimal among homeless adults in Toronto, despite universal health insurance. Multiple risk factor equations may underestimate true risk in this population due to inadequate accounting for factors such as cocaine use and heavy smoking.

abstract: Rivaroxaban, an oral factor We conducted an open-label, randomized, event-driven, non-inferiority study that compared oral rivaroxaban alone (15 mg twice daily for 3 weeks, followed by 20 mg once daily) with subcutaneous enoxaparin followed by a vitamin K antagonist (either warfarin or acenocoumarol). ) for 3, 6, or 12 months in patients with acute, symptomatic deep vein thrombosis. In parallel, we conducted a double-blind, randomized, event-driven superiority study that compared rivaroxaban alone (20 mg once daily) with placebo for an additional 6 or 12 months in patients who had completed 6 to 12 months of treatment for venous disease. Blood clots. The primary efficacy outcome for both studies was recurrent venous thromboembolism. The primary safety outcome was major bleeding or clinically relevant non-major bleeding in the initial treatment study and major bleeding in the maintenance study. The rivaroxaban study for acute DVT included 3449 patients: 1731 given rivaroxaban and 1718 given enoxaparin plus a vitamin K antagonist. Rivaroxaban had noninferior efficacy for the primary outcome (36 events [2.1%], versus 51 events with enoxaparin-vitamin K antagonist [3.0%]; hazard ratio, 0.68; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.44 to 1.04; p <0.001). Major safety outcomes occurred in 8.1% of patients in each group. In the Continuation Treatment study, which included 602 patients in the rivaroxaban group and 594 patients in the placebo group, rivaroxaban had superior efficacy (8 events [1.3%), versus 42 with placebo (7.1%); hazard ratio, 0.18; 95% CI, 0.09 to 0.39; p < 0.001. Four patients in the rivaroxaban group had nonfatal major bleeding (0.7%), versus none in the placebo group (P = 0.11). Rivaroxaban offers a simple, single-drug approach to short-term, continuous treatment of venous thrombosis that may improve the benefit-risk ratio of anticoagulation. (Funded by Bayer Schering Pharma and Ortho-McNeil; ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00440193 and NCT00439725.).

abstract: Whether the oral factor Xa inhibitor edoxaban can be an alternative to warfarin in patients with venous thromboembolism is unclear. In a randomized, double-blind, non-inferiority study, we randomly assigned patients with acute venous thromboembolism, who initially received heparin, to receive edoxaban at a dose of 60 mg once daily, or 30 mg once daily (eg, in patients Those with a creatinine clearance of 30 to 50 ml per minute or a body weight of less than 60 kg), or to receive warfarin. Patients received the study drug for 3 to 12 months. The primary efficacy outcome was symptomatic recurrent venous thromboembolism. The primary safety outcome was non-major or clinically relevant bleeding. There were a total of 4921 patients with deep vein thrombosis and 3319 with pulmonary embolism. Among patients receiving warfarin, time in therapeutic range was 63.5%. Edoxaban was noninferior to warfarin for the primary efficacy outcome, which occurred in 130 patients in the edoxaban group (3.2%) and 146 patients in the warfarin group (3.5%) (hazard ratio, 0.89; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.70 to 1.13). ; P < 0.001 for non-inferiority). Safety outcomes occurred in 349 patients (8.5%) in the edoxaban group and 423 patients (10.3%) in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.71 to 0.94; P = 0.004 for superiority). Rates of other adverse events were similar in the two groups. A total of 938 patients with pulmonary embolism had right ventricular dysfunction, as assessed by measuring N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide levels; The rate of recurrent venous thromboembolism in this subgroup was 3.3% in the edoxaban group and 6.2% in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.52; 95% CI, 0.28 to 0.98). Once-daily administration of edoxaban after initial heparin therapy was noninferior to standard HD therapy and caused significantly less bleeding in a wide range of patients with venous thromboembolism, including those with acute pulmonary embolism. (Funded by Daiichi-Sankyo; Hokusai-VTE ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00986154.).

abstract: Patients with acute proximal deep vein thrombosis are usually first treated in a hospital with standard (unfractionated) heparin intravenously. However, the longer plasma half-life, better bioavailability after subcutaneous administration, and more predictable anticoagulant response to lower molecular weight heparins make them attractive for potential home use. We compare these two approaches. Patients with proximal deep vein thrombosis were randomized to receive either standard heparin intravenously in the hospital (253 patients) or low-molecular-weight heparin (1 mg enoxaparin per kilogram of body weight subcutaneously twice daily) given primarily at home. (1 mg of enoxaparin per kilogram of body weight subcutaneously twice daily (247 patients). The study design allowed outpatients taking low-molecular-weight heparin to go home immediately and hospitalized patients taking low-molecular-weight heparin to be discharged early. All patients received warfarin starting on day 2. Thirteen of 247 patients receiving low-molecular-weight heparin (5.3 percent) had recurrent thromboembolism, compared with 17 of 253 patients receiving standard heparin (6.7 percent; P = 0.57; absolute difference, 1.4 percentage points; confidence interval 95 percent). , -3.0 to 5.7). Five patients receiving low-molecular-weight heparin had major bleeding, compared with three patients receiving standard heparin. After randomization, patients who received low-molecular-weight heparin spent an average of 1.1 days in the hospital, compared with 6.5 days for the standard heparin group; 120 patients in the low-molecular-weight heparin group did not require hospitalization at all. Low molecular weight heparin can be used safely and effectively to treat patients with proximal deep vein thrombosis at home.

abstract: Prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis in hospitalized patients remains underutilized. We hypothesized that use of a computer alert program to encourage prophylaxis may reduce the frequency of deep vein thrombosis among high-risk hospitalized patients. We developed a computer program linked to a patient database to identify consecutive hospitalized patients at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis in the absence of prophylaxis. The program used medical record numbers to randomly assign 1,255 eligible patients to an intervention group, in which the responsible physician was alerted to the patient's risk of deep vein thrombosis, and 1,251 patients to a control group, in which no alert was issued. The physician was required to acknowledge the alert and could then withhold or order prophylaxis, including graduated compression stockings, pneumatic compression shoes, unfractionated heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin, or warfarin. The primary endpoint was clinically diagnosed, objectively confirmed deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism within 90 days. More patients in the intervention group than in the control group received mechanical prophylaxis (10.0 percent vs. 1.5 percent, P < 0.001) or drug prophylaxis (23.6 percent vs. 13.0 percent, P < 0.001). The primary endpoint occurred in 61 patients (4.9 percent) in the intervention group, compared with 103 (8.2 percent) in the control group; Kaplan-Meier estimates of the probability of freedom from deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days were 94.1 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 92.5 to 95.4 percent) and 90.6 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 88.7 to 92.2 percent), respectively (P< 0.001). Computer stimulation reduced the risk of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism by 41 percent over 90 days (hazard ratio, 0.59; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.81; P = 0.001). The creation of a computer alert program increased physicians' use of prophylaxis and significantly reduced rates of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism among hospitalized patients at risk.

abstract: Whether closure of the foramen ovale reduces the risk of stroke recurrence in patients who have had a stroke of unknown origin is unknown. In a multicenter, randomized, open-label trial, with adjudication blinded to endpoint events, we randomly assigned patients aged 18 to 60 years who had a patent foramen ovale (PFO) and had an ischemic stroke of unknown origin to undergo foramen ovale closure. PFO (PFO closure group) or receiving medical therapy alone (aspirin, warfarin, clopidogrel, or aspirin with extended-release dipyridamole; medical therapy group). The primary efficacy endpoint was the combination of recurrent nonfatal ischemic stroke, fatal ischemic stroke, or early death after randomization. Results of the primary outcome analysis from the original trial period have been reported previously; The present analysis of data from the extended follow-up period was considered exploratory. We enrolled 980 patients (mean age 45.9 years) at 69 sites. Patients were followed for an average of 5.9 years. The treatment exposure in the two groups was unequal (3141 patient years in the PFO closure group versus 2669 patient years in the medical therapy group), due to a higher dropout rate in the medical therapy group. In the treatment target population, recurrent ischemic stroke occurred in 18 patients in the PFO closure group and in 28 patients in the medical therapy group, resulting in rates of 0.58 events per 100 patient-years and 1.07 events per 100 patient-years. years, respectively (hazard ratio with PFO closure versus medical therapy, 0.55; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.31 to 0.999; P = 0.046 by log-rank test). Recurrent ischemic stroke of undetermined cause occurred in 10 patients in the PFO closure group and in 23 patients in the medical therapy group (hazard ratio, 0.38; 95% CI, 0.18 to 0.79; P = 0.007). Venous thromboembolism (which included pulmonary embolism events and deep vein thrombosis) was more common in the PFO-closed group than in the medical therapy group. Among adults who had an ischemic stroke of unknown origin, PFO closure was associated with a lower rate of recurrent ischemic strokes compared with medical therapy alone during extended follow-up. (Funded by St. Jude Medical Corporation; RESPECT ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00465270.).

abstract: Individuals who have had a transient ischemic attack and stroke are at high risk of recurrent stroke and death. While acetylsalicylic acid (ASA, aspirin) has been established and accepted as standard treatment in these patients, recent trials have shown that a combination of ASA and dipyridamole (DP) or clopidogrel may be superior to ASA. Blocking the renin-angiotensin system with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers may also reduce recurrent stroke. The PROFESS (Prevention System to Effectively Avoid Second Strokes) trial was designed to evaluate whether extended-release ASA + DP compared with clopidogrel, and whether telmisartan in addition to usual care for individuals after stroke, will reduce the risk of further strokes. PROFESS is a multicenter, double-blind, randomized trial including 695 sites from 35 countries or regions. Patients over 50 years of age who had an ischemic stroke of less than 120 days of age and who were stable were randomized. The primary outcome of the trial is recurrent stroke, using time-to-event analysis. The most important secondary outcome is stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. Other secondary outcomes include this combination + congestive heart failure, new-onset diabetes, and other specific vascular occlusive events (pulmonary embolus, deep vein thrombosis, peripheral arterial occlusion, transient ischemic attack, cerebral venous thrombosis, or retinal vascular accident not classified). As a stroke), any death, or a subtype of stroke according to the TOAST criteria and the Mini-Mental State Examination score. Safety is evaluated by assessing the risk of major bleeding events. The comparison between ASA + DP and clopidogrel is based on an initial non-inferiority assessment, followed by a superiority assessment, while for telmisartan, we will evaluate its superiority over placebo. With more than 20,000 patients randomized, and using a 2 × 2 factorial design, PROFESS is the largest stroke trial to investigate the prevention of recurrent stroke. The mean age was 66.1 +/- 8.6 years, and 36.0% of patients were female. The median time from qualifying event to randomization was 15 days with 39.9% of patients randomized within 10 days. According to the TOAST criteria, 28.5% of strokes were due to large vessel disease, 52.1% were due to small vessel disease, 1.8% were due to cardioembolism, 2.0% were due to other specified etiology, and 15.5% were due to undetermined etiology. . PROFESS is the largest secondary stroke prevention trial to date and will directly compare two antiplatelet regimens as well as the benefit of telmisartan versus placebo.

abstract: The risk of bleeding complications during and after early hip fracture surgery has not been established for patients taking clopidogrel and other anticoagulants. The purpose of this study is to evaluate perioperative bleeding risks and clinical outcomes after early hip fracture surgery in patients taking clopidogrel (Plavix) and other oral anticoagulants. The study design is a retrospective cohort analysis using data extracted from hospital records and government death registries. Regional Medical Center (Level II Trauma). Data on 1118 patients aged ≥60 years who underwent surgical treatment for hip fracture between 2004 and 2008 were reviewed. Eighty-two patients undergoing late surgery (>3 days after admission) were excluded. Patients taking clopidogrel were compared with those not taking clopidogrel. In addition, patients taking clopidogrel only were compared with groups of patients taking clopidogrel and aspirin, aspirin only, warfarin only, or no anticoagulants. Seventy-four of 1036 patients (7%) were taking clopidogrel, although the control groups included 253 patients taking aspirin alone, 90 patients taking warfarin, and 619 patients not taking anticoagulants. No statistically significant differences were observed between patients taking clopidogrel and those not taking clopidogrel in estimated blood loss, transfusion requirements, final blood count, hematoma evacuation, hospital length of stay (LOS), or mortality. While they are in the hospital or after one year. A higher American Society of Anesthesiologists score was seen in the clopidogrel and warfarin groups (P = 0.05 for each), an increased LOS in the clopidogrel group (P = 0.05), and a higher rate of deep vein thrombosis in those patients taking warfarin (P = 0.05). 0.05). Clopidogrel alone versus aspirin versus both aspirin and clopidogrel, versus no anticoagulant versus warfarin, showed no significant differences in estimated blood loss, transfusion requirements, final blood counts, bleeding, perioperative complications, or mortality. Patients undergoing early hip fracture surgery who take clopidogrel, aspirin, or warfarin (with an internationally regulated normalized ratio) are not at increased risk of bleeding, bleeding complications, or death. Comorbidities and American Society of Anesthesiologists scores were significantly higher in the clopidogrel group, which may lead to increased postoperative visual loss in this group.

abstract: Several newer anticoagulants are in clinical development. Two of them recently, Dabigatran etexilate/Pradaxa. Rivaroxaban/Xarelto has marketing authorization in Europe and Canada for the prevention of thromboembolic events after major orthopedic surgery such as total hip and knee replacement. Results of phase III clinical studies in thromboprophylaxis in major orthopedic surgery are highlighted and discussed in detail. Ongoing phase II and III clinical trials are evaluating its effectiveness in the prevention and secondary treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, in the long-term prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation and in combination with aspirin and clopidogrel in patients with aspirin and clopidogrel. With acute coronary syndromes. Several other anticoagulant small molecules, including a new generation of low-molecular-weight heparin, are currently in various stages of clinical development. In addition to oral administration, newer anticoagulants have a more balanced benefit/risk ratio and a wider therapeutic window. They have a rapid onset of action, a predictable anticoagulant effect and do not require routine laboratory monitoring. They have minor interactions with food and drugs, including interactions with cytochrome P450 and P.gp. They are highly specific, target a single clotting factor, and can carry a similar or lower bleeding risk compared to older anticoagulant agents. Finally, it can be used in a wide range of patients, especially patients with advanced cancer, the elderly without any dose adjustment, regardless of the patient's age, sex or body weight or in patients with mild renal impairment. It is hoped that its use in the general world will confirm the promising results of clinical trials.

abstract: Allopurinol, a drug commonly prescribed to treat gout and hyperuricemia, is a frequent cause of severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCAR), which include drug hypersensitivity syndrome, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis. Adverse events are unpredictable and carry significant morbidity and mortality. To identify genetic markers for allopurinol-SCAR, we performed a case-control association study. We enrolled 51 allopurinol-SCAR patients and 228 control subjects (135 allopurinol-tolerant subjects and 93 healthy subjects from the general population), and genotyped 823 SNPs in genes associated with drug metabolism and immune response. The initial screen revealed a strong association between allopurinol-SCAR and SNPs in the MHC region, including BAT3 (encoding HLA-B associated transcript 3), MSH5 (mutS Homolog 5), and MICB (MHC class B polypeptide-binding sequence) ( P) < 10(-7)). We next identified HLA loci A, B, C, and DRB1 alleles. The HLA-B*5801 allele was present in all 51 (100%) patients with allopurinol-SCAR, but only in 20 (15%) of the 135 tolerant patients [odds ratio, 580.3 (95% confidence interval, 34.4-9780.9 ); corrected P value = 4.7 × 10(-24)] and in 19 (20%) of 93 healthy subjects [393.51 (23.23-6665.26); Corrected P value = 8.1 × 10(-18)]. HLA A*3303, Cw*0302, and DRB1*0301 alleles were in linkage disequilibrium and formed an extended haplotype with HLA-B*5801. Our results indicated that allopurinol-SCAR is strongly associated with genetic predisposition in Han Chinese. In particular, the HLA-B*5801 allele is an important genetic risk factor for this life-threatening condition.

abstract: Develop evidence-based recommendations for the management of gout. The multidisciplinary guideline development group consisted of 19 rheumatologists and one expert in evidence-based medicine representing 13 European countries. Key propositions on governance were generated using a Delphi consensus approach. The research evidence was systematically searched for each proposal. Where possible, effect size (ES), number needed to treat, relative risk, odds ratio, and incremental cost-effectiveness ratio were calculated. The quality of evidence was graded according to the level of evidence. Strength of recommendation (SOR) was assessed using EULAR analog and ordinal scales. 12 major propositions were generated after three rounds of Delphi. The proposals included both pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments and addressed the control of acute gout symptoms, urate-lowering therapy (ULT), and prevention of acute attacks. The importance of patient education, adverse lifestyle modification (weight loss in obesity, reduced alcohol consumption, low animal purine diet) and treatment of comorbidities and associated risk factors is emphasized. Recommended medications for acute attacks were oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), oral colchicine (ES = 0.87 (95% CI, 0.25 to 1.50)), or joint aspiration and corticosteroid injections. ULT is indicated in patients with recurrent acute attacks, arthropathy, tophi, or radiographic changes of gout. The long-term effectiveness of allopurinol for lowering urate levels was confirmed (ES = 1.39 (0.78 to 2.01)). If allopurinol toxicity occurs, options include other xanthine oxidase inhibitors, allopurinol desensitization, or increased uric acid. Benzbromarone uric acid is more effective than allopurinol (ES = 1.50 (0.76 to 2.24)) and can be used in patients with mild to moderate renal insufficiency but may be hepatotoxic. When gout is associated with the use of diuretics, diuretics should be discontinued if possible. To prevent acute attacks, colchicine 0.5-1 mg daily or NSAIDs (with gastric protection if necessary) are recommended. 12 key recommendations for the management of gout have been developed, using a combination of research-based evidence and expert consensus. The evidence was evaluated and an SOR was provided for each proposal.

abstract: Febuxostat, a new selective nonpurinyl xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is a potential alternative to allopurinol for patients with hyperuricemia and gout. We randomly assigned 762 patients with gout and blood urate concentrations of at least 8.0 mg per deciliter (480 μmol per liter) to receive either febuxostat (80 mg or 120 mg) or allopurinol (300 mg) once daily for 52 weeks; 760 received study medication. Prophylaxis against gout attacks was provided with naproxen or colchicine during weeks 1 through 8. The primary endpoint was a serum urate concentration of less than 6.0 mg per deciliter (360 μmol per liter) at the last three monthly measurements. Secondary endpoints included a reduction in the incidence of gout attacks and in the area of ​​tophi. The primary endpoint was reached in 53% of patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat, 62% of those receiving 120 mg febuxostat, and 21% of patients receiving allopurinol (P < 0.001 to compare each febuxostat group with the allopurinol group). . Although the incidence of gout attacks diminished as treatment continued, the overall incidence during weeks 9 to 52 was similar in all groups: 64% of patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat, 70% of those receiving 120 mg febuxostat. , and 64% of those receiving 120 mg of febuxostat. Receiving allopurinol (P = 0.99 for 80 mg febuxostat versus allopurinol; P = 0.23 for 120 mg febuxostat versus allopurinol). The mean reduction in tophi area was 83 percent in patients receiving 80 mg of febuxostat and 66 percent in those receiving 120 mg of febuxostat, compared with 50 percent in those receiving allopurinol (P = 0.08 for 80 mg of febuxostat versus allopurinol; P =0.16 for 120 mg febuxostat versus allopurinol). More patients in the high-dose febuxostat group than in the allopurinol group (P = 0.003) or the low-dose febuxostat group discontinued the study. Four of the 507 patients in the two groups died on febuxostat (0.8 percent) and none of the 253 patients in the allopurinol group died. All deaths were due to causes that the investigators (while still blind to treatment) considered unrelated to the study medications (P = 0.31 for comparison between the combined febuxostat and allopurinol groups). Febuxostat, at a daily dose of 80 mg or 120 mg, was more effective than allopurinol at the commonly used fixed daily dose of 300 mg in lowering serum urate. Similar reductions in gout flares and tophi area occurred in all treatment groups.

abstract: The prototypical xanthine oxidase (XO) inhibitor, allopurinol, has been the cornerstone of the clinical management of gout and associated conditions of hyperuricemia for several decades. More recent data suggest that XO also plays an important role in various forms of vascular ischemia and other types of tissue and vascular injuries, inflammatory diseases, and chronic heart failure. Allopurinol and its active metabolite oxypurinol have shown great promise in treating these conditions both in laboratory animals and in small-scale human clinical trials. Although some of the beneficial effects of these compounds may not be related to XO inhibition, the encouraging results have sparked great interest in developing new additional series of XO inhibitors for various therapeutic indications. Here we provide a critical overview of the effects of XO inhibitors in various pathophysiological conditions and also review the various emerging therapeutic strategies offered by this approach.

abstract: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in people with primary fibromyalgia, with or without coexisting major depressive disorder. This study was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial conducted at 18 outpatient research centers in the United States. A total of 207 subjects meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for primary fibromyalgia were enrolled (89% female, 87% white, mean age 49 years, 38% with current major depressive disorder). After single-blind placebo treatment for 1 week, subjects were randomly assigned to receive duloxetine 60 mg twice a day (n = 104) or placebo (n = 103) for 12 weeks. Co-primary outcome measures were the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) total score (score range 0–80, with 0 indicating no effect) and FIQ pain score (score range 0–10). Secondary outcome measures included mean pain threshold at pain point, number of pain scores, FIQ fatigue, fatigue on awakening, stiffness scores, Clinical Global Impression of Severity (CGI-Severity), and Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-Improvement) scale. Brief Pain Inventory (Short Form), Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 36, Quality of Life Depression Scale, and Sheehan Disability Scale. Compared with subjects treated with placebo, duloxetine-treated subjects improved significantly (P = 0.027) on the FIQ total score, with a treatment difference of -5.53 (95% CI -10.43, -0.63), but not significantly more on the FIQ score. Pain recurred (P = 0.130). Compared with subjects treated with placebo, subjects treated with duloxetine had significantly greater reductions in the average Brief Pain Inventory pain intensity score (P = 0.008), the average Brief Pain Inventory pain intensity score (P = 0.004), and the number Pain score (P = 0.002), FIQ stiffness score (P = 0.048), and there was a significantly greater improvement in the mean pain threshold of the pain score (P = 0.002), CGI severity score (P = 0.048), and PGI improvement ( P = 0.033), and several quality of life measures, duloxetine treatment showed improvement in fibromyalgia symptoms and pain severity regardless of underlying major depressive disorder status (n = 92). 92) showed significantly greater improvement on most efficacy measures, while males treated with duloxetine (n=12) failed to improve significantly on any efficacy measure. The effect of treatment on significant pain reduction in females was independent of the effect on mood or anxiety Given safely and well-tolerated in this 12-week randomized controlled trial (with a 1-week placebo phase), duloxetine was an effective and safe treatment for several symptoms associated with fibromyalgia in people with and without the disorder. Major depression, especially for women. , which had significant improvement in most outcome measures.

abstract: This was a 12-week, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in 354 female patients with primary fibromyalgia, with or without coexisting major depressive disorder. Patients (90% Caucasian; mean age, 49.6 years; 26% with current major depressive disorder) received duloxetine 60 mg once daily (QD) (n = 118), or duloxetine 60 mg twice daily (BID) (n = 116), or placebo (n = 120). The primary outcome was the average pain intensity score on the Brief Pain Inventory. Response to treatment was defined as > or = 30% reduction in this outcome. Compared with placebo, both duloxetine-treated groups improved significantly (P < 0.001) in their average pain intensity score on the Brief Pain Inventory. A significantly higher proportion of patients treated with duloxetine had a > or = 30% reduction in this outcome (duloxetine 60 mg QD (55%; P < 0.001); duloxetine 60 mg BID (54%; P = 0.002); placebo ( 54%; P = 0.002); The effect of duloxetine treatment on pain reduction was independent of the effect on mood and the presence of major depressive disorder. Compared with patients who took placebo, patients treated with duloxetine 60 mg QD or duloxetine 60 mg twice daily had significantly greater improvement in the Brief Pain Inventory residual pain severity and interference scores, the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire, the Clinical Global Impression of Disease Severity, and the Impression Patient's global assessment of improvement, and many quality of life measures. Both doses of duloxetine were administered safely and well tolerated. In conclusion, both duloxetine 60 mg QD and duloxetine 60 mg BID were effective and safe in the treatment of fibromyalgia in female patients with and without major depressive disorder.

abstract: The primary objectives of this study were to evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine for reducing pain intensity in fibromyalgia patients with and without coexisting major depressive disorder. This was a 6-month, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. In total, 520 patients meeting the American College of Rheumatology criteria for fibromyalgia were randomly assigned to duloxetine (20 mg/day, 60 mg/day, or 120 mg/day) or placebo, given once daily for 6 months ( After 3 months, the duloxetine group (20 mg/day) was titrated to 60 mg/day). Co-primary outcome measures were the average Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) pain intensity score and the Patient Global Impressions of Improvement (PGI-I) score. Safety was assessed by treatment-induced adverse events, changes in vital signs, laboratory, and ECG measurements. Compared with patients treated with placebo, those patients treated with duloxetine 120 mg/day significantly improved on combined primary outcome measures after 3 months (change in BMI score [-2.31 vs -1.39, P<0.001] and PGI-I [ -] 2.89 vs. 3.39, P = 0.004]) and after 6 months (change in BPI [-2.26 vs -1.43, P = 0.003] and PGI-I [2.93 vs. 3.37, P = 0.012]). Compared with placebo, treatment with duloxetine 60 mg/day resulted in significant improvement in the combined primary measures at 3 months and the blood pressure index at 6 months. Duloxetine has been effective in patients with and without major depressive disorder. There were no clinically significant differences between treatment groups in changes in vital signs, laboratory measurements, or ECG measurements. Study results show that duloxetine at doses of 60 mg/day and 120 mg/day appears safe and effective in patients with fibromyalgia.
