abstract: Duloxetine is a balanced serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor licensed for the treatment of major depressive disorders, stress urinary incontinence, and the management of neuropathic pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy. A number of trials have been performed to investigate the use of duloxetine in neuropathic and nociceptive painful conditions. This is the first update of a review first published in 2010. To evaluate the benefits and harms of duloxetine for the treatment of painful neuropathy and different types of chronic pain. On 19 November 2013, we searched the Cochrane Neuromuscular Group Specialist Register, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHSEED, MEDLINE, and EMBASE. We searched ClinicalTrials.gov for ongoing trials in April 2013. We also searched reference lists of publications identifying trials of duloxetine for the treatment of painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain. We selected all randomized or quasi-randomized trials of any combination of duloxetine used to treat painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain in adults. We used standard methodological procedures expected by the Cochrane Collaboration. We identified 18 trials, which included 6407 participants. We found 12 such studies in the literature looking for this update. Eight studies included a total of 2728 participants with painful diabetic neuropathy and six studies included 2249 participants with fibromyalgia. Three studies included participants with depression and painful physical symptoms and one included participants with central neuropathic pain. Studies were mostly at low risk of bias, although large dropouts, inclusion methods, and almost every study conducted or sponsored by the drug manufacturer increase the risk of bias in some areas. Duloxetine at a dose of 60 mg daily is effective in the short-term treatment of painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy, with a risk ratio (RR) for ≥50% pain reduction at 12 weeks of 1.73 (95% CI 1.44 to 2.08). The relevant NNTB is 5 (95% CI 4 to 7). Duloxetine at a dose of 60 mg daily is also effective in treating fibromyalgia over 12 weeks (RR for pain reduction ≥ 50% 1.57, 95% CI 1.20 to 2.06; NNTB 8, 95% CI 4 to 21) and over 28 weeks (RR NNTB 8, 95% CI 5 to 14) as well as for painful somatic symptoms in depression (RR 1.58, 95% CI 1.10 to 2.27). There was no effect on central neuropathic pain in one small, high-quality trial. In all cases, adverse events were common in both the treatment and placebo arms but more common in the treatment arm, with a dose-dependent effect. Most adverse effects were minor, but 16% of participants stopped taking the medication due to adverse effects. Serious adverse events were rare. There are sufficient amounts of moderate quality evidence from eight studies conducted by the manufacturers of duloxetine that doses of 60 mg and 120 mg daily are effective in treating pain in diabetic peripheral neuropathy but that lower daily doses are not. There is no need for further experiments. In fibromyalgia, there is less good evidence that duloxetine is effective at doses similar to those used in diabetic peripheral neuropathy and with a similar magnitude of effect. The effect in fibromyalgia may be achieved through greater improvement in mental symptoms compared to physical pain. There is low to moderate quality evidence that pain relief is also achieved in pain associated with depressive symptoms, but an NNTB of 8 in fibromyalgia and depression is not an indicator of significant efficacy. Further trials (preferably independent investigator-led studies) are needed in these indications to reach the optimal amount of information to make convincing decisions about effectiveness. Minor side effects are common and are more common with duloxetine 60 mg and especially with 120 mg daily, more than 20 mg daily, but serious side effects are rare. Improved direct comparisons between duloxetine with other antidepressants and with other drugs, such as pregabalin, which have already been shown to be effective in treating neuropathic pain, would be appropriate. Unbiased economic comparisons would aid decision making further, but there is no high-quality study that includes economic data.

abstract: Peripheral artery disease is a manifestation of systemic atherosclerosis with associated adverse cardiovascular and extremity events. Data from previous trials have indicated that patients receiving clopidogrel monotherapy have a lower risk of cardiovascular disease compared with those receiving aspirin. We wanted to compare clopidogrel with ticagrelor, a powerful antiplatelet agent, in patients with peripheral artery disease. In this double-blind, event-based trial, we randomly assigned 13,885 patients with symptomatic PAD to receive monotherapy with ticagrelor (90 mg twice daily) or clopidogrel (75 mg once daily). Patients were eligible if they had an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.80 or less or had undergone previous lower extremity revascularization. The primary efficacy endpoint was a composite of cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, or ischemic stroke. The primary safety endpoint was major bleeding. Median follow-up was 30 months. The average age of patients was 66 years, and 72% were men; 43% were enrolled on the basis of ABI and 57% on the basis of previous revascularization. The mean baseline ABI in all patients was 0.71, 76.6% of patients had claudication, and 4.6% had critical limb ischemia. The primary efficacy endpoint occurred in 751 of 6930 patients (10.8%) who received ticagrelor and in 740 of 6955 (10.6%) who received clopidogrel (hazard ratio, 1.02; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.92 to 1.13; P = 0.65). . In each group, acute limb ischemia occurred in 1.7% of patients (hazard ratio, 1.03; 95% CI, 0.79 to 1.33; P=0.85) and major bleeding in 1.6% (hazard ratio, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.84 to 1.43). ; P = 0.49). In patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease, ticagrelor has not been shown to be superior to clopidogrel in reducing cardiovascular events. Major bleeding occurred at similar rates between patients in the two trial groups. (Funded by AstraZeneca; EUCLID ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01732822.).

abstract: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) affects approximately 20% of adults over the age of 55 years and is a strong predictor of myocardial infarction, stroke, and death from vascular causes. The goals of treatment are to prevent future major coronary and cerebrovascular events and improve leg symptoms. To review the best evidence for medical treatment of peripheral artery disease. MEDLINE and the Cochrane Database were searched from 1990 to November 2005 for randomized trials and meta-analyses of medical treatments for peripheral artery disease. References from these articles were also searched. Search terms, individually or in combination, included: peripheral arterial disease, peripheral artery disease, PAD, randomized controlled trial, randomized controlled trial, and meta-analysis. Particular attention has been directed toward randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses of clinically relevant medical treatments for peripheral artery disease. Outcome measures included leg symptoms (intermittent claudication and walking distance), death, and major coronary and cerebrovascular events. Leg claudication symptoms, walking distance, and quality of life can be improved by smoking cessation (doctor's advice, nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion), a structured exercise program, statins, cilostazol, and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. The risk of major coronary and cerebrovascular events can be reduced by lowering blood pressure with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and other antihypertensive drugs, use of statins, antiplatelet therapy with aspirin or clopidogrel, and possibly by smoking cessation. The large and increasing burden of peripheral artery disease, and its local and systemic complications, can be reduced by lifestyle modification (smoking cessation, exercise) and medical treatments (nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion, antihypertensive drugs, statins, and antiplatelet drugs).

abstract: Incomplete inhibition of platelet thromboxane synthesis, as measured by elevated urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations, has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. We aimed to determine the external validity of this association in aspirin-treated patients enrolled in the Clopidogrel for High Atherosclerosis Risk and Ischemia Stabilization, Management and Avoidance (CHARISMA) trial and to determine whether there are any modifiable factors or interventions that lead to lowering urate. Dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations can thus reduce cardiovascular risk. 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations were measured in 3261 aspirin-treated patients at least 1 month after they were randomized to placebo or clopidogrel. Baseline urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations in the highest quartile were associated with an increased risk of stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death compared with the lowest quartile (adjusted hazard ratio 1.66, 95% CI 1.06 to 2.61, P = 0.03). . Increasing age, female sex, history of peripheral artery disease, current smoking, and treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or oral hypoglycemia were independently associated with increased urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations, while aspirin dose > or = 150 mg/d, history of treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, history of hypercholesterolemia, and statin therapy were associated with lower concentrations. Randomization to clopidogrel (versus placebo) did not reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients in the highest quartile of urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) levels. In patients treated with aspirin, urinary concentrations of 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) are a valid, externally modifiable determinant of stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death in patients at risk for atherothrombotic events.

abstract: This guideline focuses on anticoagulant drug therapies for the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease as well as for the relief of lower extremity symptoms and critical ischemia in people with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The methods for this guideline follow those described in the Methodology for the Development of Anticoagulant Therapy and Thromboprophylaxis: Anticoagulant Therapy and Thrombosis Prophylaxis, Ninth Edition: Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines of the American College of Chest Physicians in this supplement. Our top 20 recommendations are as follows. In patients aged ≥ 50 years with asymptomatic peripheral artery disease or asymptomatic carotid stenosis, we suggest aspirin (75-100 mg/day) without treatment (Grade 2b) for the primary prevention of cardiovascular events. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (including patients before and after peripheral artery bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty), we recommend long-term aspirin (75-100 mg/day). or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) (Grade 1A). We recommend that warfarin not be used in addition to aspirin in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (grade 1b). For patients undergoing percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with stenting, we suggest single antiplatelet therapy rather than dual therapy (grade 2C). For patients with refractory claudication despite exercise therapy and smoking cessation, we suggest adding cilostazol (100 mg per day) to aspirin (75-100 mg per day) or clopidogrel (75 mg per day) (Grade 2C). In patients with critical limb ischemia and rest pain who are unable to undergo revascularization, we suggest the use of prostanoids (grade 2C). In patients with acute limb ischemia due to acute thrombosis or embolism, we recommend surgery to treat peripheral arterial thrombosis (Grade 1B). Recommendations continue to favor individualized antiplatelet therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular events in most patients with asymptomatic PAD, symptomatic PAD, and asymptomatic carotid stenosis. Additional treatments to relieve extremity symptoms should be considered only after exercise therapy, smoking cessation, and evaluation of peripheral artery revascularization.

abstract: Bleeding, a common complication of treatment for acute myocardial infarction (AMI), is associated with worse outcomes. The contemporary model of major bleeding associated with AMI treatment can stratify patients at high risk of bleeding and is essential for adjusting AMI practice and outcomes. Using the Acute Coronary Intervention and Treatment Outcomes Network-Get Guidelines database (ACTION Registry-GWTG), an in-hospital major bleeding risk model was developed in a cohort of patients with ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction and non-ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction. High segment - myocardial infarction. The model used only baseline variables and was developed (n = 72,313) and validated (n = 17,960) in patients with AMI (at 251 US centers from January 2007 to December 2008). The 12 most statistically and clinically significant variables were combined in the final regression model. Calibration plots are shown, and model discrimination is shown across the derivation and validation sets, as well as across the major subsets. The major bleeding rate in the overall population was 10.8%. The 12 factors associated with major bleeding in the model were heart rate, baseline hemoglobin, female sex, baseline serum creatinine, age, ECG changes, heart failure or shock, diabetes, peripheral artery disease, body weight, and systolic blood pressure. And home warfarin. Uses. The model discriminated risks well in the derivation (C-statistic = 0.73) and validation (C-statistic = 0.71) cohorts. The risk score for major bleeding corresponded well to significant bleeding: very low risk (3.9%), low risk (7.3%), moderate risk (16.1%), high risk (29.0%), and very high risk (39.8%). In conclusion, the ACTION Registry-GWTG hospital major bleeding model stratifies the risk of major bleeding using variables at presentation and enables risk-adjusted bleeding outcomes for quality improvement initiatives and clinical decision making.

abstract: The combination of anticoagulant therapy and antiplatelet therapy is more effective than antiplatelet therapy alone in the initial and long-term management of acute coronary syndromes but increases the risk of bleeding. Antiplatelet therapy is often combined with oral anticoagulants in patients who have an indication for warfarin therapy (eg, atrial fibrillation) and who also have an indication for antiplatelet therapy (eg, coronary artery disease) but the suitability of such an approach is not yet resolved. Anticoagulation appears to be as effective as antiplatelet therapy in the long-term management of acute coronary syndrome, stroke, and possibly peripheral artery disease, but causes more bleeding. Therefore, in those patients who develop atrial fibrillation, a switch from antiplatelet therapy to anticoagulants may be all that is needed. The combination of anticoagulant and antiplatelet therapy has been shown to provide additional benefit compared with anticoagulants alone in patients with prosthetic heart valves. The combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is not as effective as oral anticoagulants in patients with atrial fibrillation, while the combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is more effective than oral anticoagulants in patients with coronary stenting. Whether the benefits of triple therapy outweigh the risks in patients with atrial fibrillation and coronary stenting requires evaluation in randomized trials.

abstract: Vascular disease is included in the risk scoring system for predicting stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation (AF). This post-hoc analysis of ROCKET AF aims to determine the absolute rates of stroke and bleeding, and the relative efficacy and safety of rivaroxaban versus warfarin in patients with and without peripheral artery disease (PAD). Peripheral artery disease was defined in the case report form as the presence of intermittent claudication, amputation due to arterial insufficiency, endovascular reconstruction, bypass surgery, percutaneous extremity intervention, or previously documented abdominal aortic aneurysm. The ROCKET AF trial was a double-blind, double-dummy, randomized controlled trial comparing rivaroxaban with warfarin for the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism. A total of 839 (5.9%) patients in ROCKET AF had PAD. Patients with and without peripheral artery disease had similar rates of stroke or systemic embolism [HR: 1.04, 95% CI (0.72, 1.50), P = 0.84] and major or non-major clinically relevant bleeding (NMCR) [HR : 1.11, 95%) CI (0.96, 1.28), P = 0.17], respectively. The effectiveness of rivaroxaban when compared with warfarin for the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism was similar in patients with peripheral artery disease (HR: 1.19, 95% CI: 0.63-2.22) and those without peripheral artery disease (HR: 0.86, CI). 95%: 0.73-1.02). Interaction F = 0.34). There was a significant interaction of major bleeding or NMCR bleeding in patients with peripheral artery disease treated with rivaroxaban compared with warfarin (HR: 1.40, 95% CI: 1.06-1.86) compared with those without peripheral artery disease (HR: 1.40, 95% CI: 1.06-1.86). 1.03, 95% CI: 0.95-1.11). Interaction P = 0.037). Patients with peripheral artery disease in ROCKET AF did not have a statistically significantly higher risk of stroke or systemic embolism compared with patients without peripheral artery disease, and there were similar efficacy results in patients treated with rivaroxaban and warfarin. In PAD patients, there was a greater risk of major bleeding or NMCR bleeding with rivaroxaban compared with warfarin (interaction P = 0.037). Further investigation is warranted to validate this subgroup analysis and determine optimal treatment in this high-risk group of atrial fibrillation patients with PAD.

abstract: The management of warfarin therapy is complicated by the large inter-patient variability in response to the drug. Variants in the gene that encodes vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1 (VKORC1) may affect response to warfarin. We performed a retrospective study of European American patients receiving long-term warfarin maintenance therapy. Multiple linear regression analysis was used to determine the effect of VKORC1 haplotypes on warfarin dose. We determined VKORC1 haplotype frequencies in African American, European American, and Asian American populations and VKORC1 messenger RNA (mRNA) expression in human liver samples. We identified 10 common VKORC1 non-coding single-nucleotide polymorphisms and deduced five major haplotypes. We defined the low-dose haplotype group (A) and the high-dose haplotype group (B). The mean (+/-SE) maintenance dose of warfarin differed significantly between the three haplotype group groups, at 2.7 +/- 0.2 mg per day for A/A, and 4.9 +/- 0.2 mg per day for A/B, and 6.2 +/- 0.3 mg daily for B/B (P < 0.001). VKORC1 haplotype groups A and B explained approximately 25 percent of the variation in dose. Asian Americans had a higher proportion of group A haplotypes, and African Americans had a higher proportion of group B haplotypes. VKORC1 mRNA levels vary according to haplotype group. VKORC1 haplotypes can be used to stratify patients into low-, medium-, and high-dose warfarin groups and may explain differences in dose requirements between patients of different ancestry. The molecular mechanism of warfarin dose response appears to be regulated at the transcriptional level.

abstract: Coumarin derivatives such as warfarin represent the treatment of choice for long-term treatment and prevention of thromboembolic events. Coumarin targets blood clotting by inhibiting vitamin K multiprotein reductase (VKOR). This complex recycles vitamin K 2,3-epoxide to vitamin K hydroquinone, an essential cofactor for the post-translational gamma carboxylation of many blood clotting factors. Despite extensive efforts, the components of the VKOR complex have not been identified. The complex has been proposed to be involved in two genetic human diseases: vitamin K-dependent coagulation factor deficiency type 2 (VKCFD2; Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) 607473), and resistance to coumarin-type anticoagulant drugs (warfarin). Resistivity, WR; OMIM 122700). Here we identify, using binding information from three species, subunit 1 of the vitamin K epoxide reductase gene (VKORC1), which encodes a small transmembrane protein of the endoplasmic reticulum. VKORC1 contains missense mutations in both human disorders and in a warfarin-resistant mouse strain. Overexpression of wild-type VKORC1, but not VKORC1 carrying a VKCFD2 mutation, results in a marked increase in VKOR activity, which is sensitive to warfarin inhibition.

abstract: Current dosing algorithms do not take into account genetic and environmental factors to determine the warfarin dose. This study investigated the contribution of age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and body size to warfarin dose requirements. The study included 297 patients with stable anticoagulation with a target international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.0 to 3.0. Genetic analyzes for CYP2C9 (*2 and *3 alleles) and VKORC1 (polymorphism -1639) were performed and intravenous INR and plasma R- and S-warfarin concentrations were determined. Mean daily warfarin dose requirements were highest in patients with the CYP2C9 homozygous wild-type, compared with those with the *2 and *3 variant alleles (P < .001) and highest in patients with the VKORC1 genotype. (position -1639) GG compared with those with the GA genotype and the AA genotype (P < .001). The average daily dose requirement of warfarin decreased by 0.5 to 0.7 mg per decade between ages 20 to 90 years. Age, height, and CYP2C9 genotype contributed significantly to S-warfarin clearance and complete warfarin clearance, whereas only age and body size significantly contributed to R-warfarin clearance. A multivariable regression model including the variables age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and height produced the best model for estimating warfarin dose (R2 = 55%). Based on the data, a new warfarin dosing regimen was developed. The dosing regimen was validated in a second group of patients receiving warfarin therapy.

abstract: Initiating warfarin therapy using trial-and-error dosing is difficult. Our goal was to develop and validate a pharmacokinetic algorithm. In the derivation cohort of 1015 participants, independent predictors of therapeutic dose were: VKORC1 -1639/3673 G>A polymorphism (-28% per allele), body surface area (BSA) (+11% per 0.25 m(2)) , CYP2C9(*)3 (-33% per allele), CYP2C9(*)2 (-19% per allele), Age (-7% per decade), Target International Normalized Ratio (INR) (+11% per 0.5 units increase), amiodarone use (-22%), smoker status (+10%), race (-9%), and current coagulopathy (+7%). This pharmacokinetic equation explained 53–54% of the variance in warfarin dose in the derivation and validation cohorts (n = 292). For comparison, clinical equation explained only 17-22% of dose variance (P < 0.001). In the validation cohort, we prospectively used a drug dosing algorithm in patients who initiated warfarin therapy, two of whom had major bleeding. To facilitate the use of these pharmacological and clinical algorithms, we have developed a non-profit website, http://www.WarfarinDosing.org.

abstract: Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying individuals most at risk of harm from certain drugs. Routine adoption of pharmaceutical tests requires evidence of their cost-effectiveness. The present review aims to systematically review published economic evaluations of drug tests aimed at preventing or reducing the occurrence of adverse drug reactions. We conducted a systematic literature review of economic evaluations of drug tests aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. The literature was searched using Embase, MEDLINE and the NHS Economic Evaluation Database with search terms relating to drug tests, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluations and pharmaceuticals. Titles were screened independently by two reviewers. Articles considered to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened for abstract and full texts. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met inclusion criteria. There was evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of testing for HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58:01 (before allopurinol) and CYP2C19. (Before treatment with clopidogrel). Economic evidence was inconclusive for TPMT (before treatment with 6-mercaptobutene, azathioprine, and cisplatin), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (for informing genotype-guided dosing of coumarin derivatives), MTHFR (before treatment with methotrexate), and Factor V Leiden testing (before treatment with methotrexate). For oral contraception). Testing for A1555G is not cost-effective before prescribing aminoglycosides. Our systematic review identified strong evidence for the cost-effectiveness of pre-treatment genotyping with a number of common drugs. However, further analyzes and/or strong clinical evidence are necessary to make recommendations to others.

abstract: This article summarizes the discussions of the third European Science Foundation-University of Barcelona (ESF-UB) Conference in Biomedicine on Pharmacogenetics and Pharmacogenomics, held in June 2010 in Spain. It focused on practical applications in routine medical practice. We provide practical recommendations for ten different clinical situations, both approved and unapproved by regulatory bodies. We suggest some notes that may accompany the results of these tests, which indicate the best medication and doses that should be prescribed. Examples discussed include KRAS, cetuximab, panitumumab, EGFR-gefitinib, CYP2D6-tamoxifen, TPMT-azathioprine-6-mercaptopurine, VKORC1/CYP2C9-warfarin, CYP2C19-clopidogrel, HLA-B*5701-abacavir, and HLA-B*5701. -. Flucloxacillin, SLCO1B1-statins and CYP3A5-tacrolimus. We hope that these practical recommendations will help clinicians, biologists, scientists, and other health care professionals describe, perform, and interpret these genetic tests.

abstract: Serious adverse drug reactions represent the sixth leading cause of death in the United States, are the leading cause of post-marketing drug withdrawal and represent costs in the billions of US dollars each year in all developed countries. Some of these serious adverse drug reactions can be avoided by systematic screening for drug genetic risk factors. Over the past few years, regulatory agencies have introduced pharmacogenomic labeling for many drugs, but although prior genetic testing remains recommended or recommended, it is rarely mandatory due to poor evidence-based medical knowledge. Recently published ongoing randomized controlled pharmacogenomic trials will gradually make genotyping tests, such as tests for HLA-B*5701 (abacavir), TPMT (6-mercaptopurine), CYP2C9 plus VKORC1 (warfarin), and CYP3A5 (tacrolimus), mandatory. The parallel development of pharmacogenomic bedside tests will certainly lead to the establishment of gene-based prescriptions in routine medical practice.

abstract: Pharmacogenomics seeks to explain interindividual variation in response to drugs due to genetic variation. Although technological advances have provided us with easy and relatively cheap methods for genotyping, the promise of personalized medicine has not yet met our high expectations. Successful results achieved in the field of pharmacogenomics to date are, but not limited to, HLA-B*5701 screening to avoid hypersensitivity to the antiretroviral abacavir, thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) genotyping to avoid thiopurine toxicity, and CYP2C9 and CYP2C9. . VKORC1 genotyping for optimal dosing of the anticoagulant warfarin. However, there are few pharmacological examples that have entered clinical practice in the treatment of complex diseases. Unfortunately, the lack of reproducibility of observational studies involving many genes and diseases appears to be a common pattern in pharmacogenomics studies. In this article we address some methodological and statistical issues in study design, gene and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) selection, and data analysis that should be considered in future pharmacogenomics research. First, we discuss some issues related to the design of epidemiological studies, specific to pharmacogenomics research. Second, we describe some of the pros and cons of the candidate gene approach (including gene and SNP selection) and the genome-wide scanning approach. Finally, traditional and several innovative approaches have been proposed to analyze large pharmacogenomic datasets that address the issues of multiplexing and systems biology in different ways.

abstract: Cytochrome P450 2C19 (CYP2C19) is the major (or partial) cause of significant differences in the pharmacokinetics of a number of clinically important drugs. On the basis of their ability to metabolize (S)-mephenytoin or other CYP2C19 substrates, individuals can be classified as extensive metabolizers (EMs) or poor metabolizers (PMs). Eight different alleles (CYP2C19*2 to CYP2C19*8) that predict PMs have been identified. The distribution of EM and PM genotypes and phenotypes shows wide differences between ethnicities. Non-genetic factors such as enzyme inhibition and induction, aging, and liver fibrosis can also modify CYP2C19 activity. In emergency settings, approximately 80% of doses of the proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) omeprazole, lansoprazole, and pantoprazole appear to be eliminated by CYP2C19, whereas CYP3A is more important in cases of PMs. Exposure to these drugs has been observed to be five-fold higher in PMs compared to EMs for CYP2C19, and further increases occur during inhibition of alternative metabolic pathways catalyzed by CYP3A in PMs. As a result, PMs of CYP2C19 have more effective acid suppression and better healing of duodenal and gastric ulcers during treatment with omeprazole and lansoprazole compared with EMs. The pharmacoeconomic value of CYP2C19 genotyping remains unclear. Our calculations suggest that genotyping for CYP2C19 could save approximately $5,000 for every 100 Asians tested, but nothing for Caucasian patients. However, genotyping for common alleles of CYP2C19 before initiating proton pump inhibitors for the treatment of reflux disease and H. pylori infection is a cost-effective tool to determine the appropriate duration of treatment regimens and dosing. Altered CYP2C19 activity does not appear to increase the risk of adverse drug reactions/proton pump inhibitor interactions. Phenytoin plasma concentrations and toxicity have been shown to be increased in patients taking CYP2C19 inhibitors or who have variant alleles, and because of its narrow therapeutic range, genotyping for CYP2C19 in addition to CYP2C9 may be needed to optimize the dose of phenytoin. The risk of tricyclic antidepressant toxicity may be increased in patients whose CYP2C19 and/or CYP2D6 activities are diminished. CYP2C19 is a key enzyme in the activation of proguanil to cycloguanil, but there are no clinical data to suggest that PMs of CYP2C19 are at greater risk for malaria prophylaxis or treatment failure. Diazepam clearance is clearly diminished in PMs or when CYP2C19 inhibitors are co-prescribed, but clinical consequences are generally minimal. Finally, several studies have attempted to determine relationships between CYP2C19 genotype and phenotype and susceptibility to diseases caused by xenobiotics, but none of these studies have been convincing.

abstract: Voriconazole is the treatment of choice for aspergillosis and a new treatment option for candidiasis. Liver disease, age, CYP2C19 gene polymorphisms, and comedic medications affect the metabolism of voriconazole. Significant differences in voriconazole pharmacokinetics may be associated with reduced efficacy or toxicity. This study was conducted to evaluate the utility of measuring voriconazole blood levels with individual dose adjustments. A total of 181 measurements using high-pressure liquid chromatography were performed during 2388 treatment days in 52 patients. Considerable variation in blood voriconazole levels has been observed, ranging from <or=1 mg/L (minimum inhibitory concentration at which 90% of isolates are susceptible to most fungal pathogens) in 25% of cases to >5.5 mg/L. L (level possibly associated with toxicity) in 31% of cases. Non-response to treatment was more common in patients with voriconazole levels < or = 1 mg/L (6 [46%] of 13 patients, including 5 patients with aspergillosis, 4 of whom were treated orally at a median dose of 6 mg/L). kg per day) compared with those with voriconazole levels > 1 mg/L (15 [12%] of 39 patients; P = .02). Blood levels >1 mg/L were achieved after voriconazole dose increases, with complete resolution of infection in all six cases. Among 16 patients with low blood voriconazole levels >5.5 mg/L, 5 patients (31%) developed encephalopathy, including 4 patients treated intravenously with a mean voriconazole dose of 8 mg/kg daily, while no None of the patients with levels < or = 5.5 mg/L presented with neurotoxicity (P = 0.002). Chemotherapy with omeprazole may have contributed to voriconazole accumulation in 4 patients. In all cases, discontinuation of treatment resulted in rapid and complete neurological recovery. Voriconazole therapeutic drug monitoring improves the efficacy and safety of treatment in critically ill patients with invasive fungi.

abstract: Many drugs, including proton pump inhibitors and some antidepressants, are metabolized by the polymorphic enzyme cytochrome P450 (CYP) 2C19. A significant portion of the broad-spectrum metabolites do not reach appropriate drug levels, and our goal was to investigate any genetic background. The 5'-flanking region of the CYP2C19 gene from subjects with rapid omeprazole metabolizers was sequenced, and the phenotype-genotype associations of CYP2C19 in Swedish (n = 107) and Ethiopian (n = 126) were analyzed in large-scale metabolizers. The relationship between the omeprazole metabolism ratio (omeprazole/5-hydroxy omeprazole in plasma 3 hours after drug administration) with the area under the plasma concentration-time curve has been used in prediction studies. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays were performed using human nuclear protein extracts. Liver reporter vector transfections were performed into CD1 mice. We identified a novel allele (CYP2C19*17) carrying -806C>T and -3402C>T, with a frequency of 18% in both Swedes and Ethiopians and 4% in Chinese subjects. In Swedes, the rate of metabolism of omeprazole was higher in subjects homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.50 [interquartile range, 0.37-0.73]) than in those homozygous for CYP2C19*17 (median, 0.25 [interquartile range, 0.15-0.33]) ( P = .010). In Ethiopians, a similar difference in the S/R-mephenytoin ratio was observed between individuals homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.20 [interquartile range, 0.12-0.37]) and those homozygous for CYP2C19*17 (median, 0.05 [interquartile range, 0.05] 0.03). -0.06]) (P = 0.013). Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed specific binding of human hepatic nuclear proteins to a motif carrying -806T but not -806C. Reporter vector experiments demonstrated increased transcriptional activity of the CYP2C19*17 allele in vivo in mice. Projections revealed that CYP2C19*17 homozygotes would achieve 35% to 40% lower area under the plasma concentration-time curve values ​​than CYP2C19*1 homozygotes taking standard doses of omeprazole. CYP2C19*17 has the potential to cause therapeutic failure with drug therapy, for example, with proton pump inhibitors and antidepressants.

abstract: Human CYP2Cs are an important subfamily of P450 enzymes that metabolize approximately 20% of clinically used drugs. There are four members in the subfamily, CYP2C8, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, and CYP2C18. Of these, CYP2C8, CYP2C9, and CYP2C19 are of clinical importance. CYP2Cs also metabolize some endogenous compounds such as arachidonic acid. Every member of this subfamily has been found to be genetically polymorphic. The best known of these polymorphisms is in CYP2C19. Poor metabolizers (PMs) of CYP2C19 represent approximately 3-5% of Caucasians, a similar percentage of African Americans and 12-100% of Asian groups. The polymorphism affects the metabolism of the anticonvulsant agent mephenytoin, proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole, the anxiolytic agent diazepam, some antidepressants, and the antimalarial drug proguanil. Toxic effects can occur in patients with PM exposed to diazepam, and the effectiveness of some proton pump inhibitors may be greater in PM than EM at low doses of these drugs. There are a number of mutant alleles that can be detected by genetic testing. CYP2C9 metabolizes a wide range of drugs including the anticoagulant warfarin, antidiabetic agents such as tolbutamide, anticonvulsants such as phenytoin, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The incidence of functional polymorphisms is much lower, estimated at 1/250 in Caucasians and lower in Asians. However, the clinical consequences of these rare polymorphisms can be severe. Severe, life-threatening bleeding events have been reported in CYP2C9 PM patients exposed to warfarin. Phenytoin has been reported to cause severe toxicity in PMs. New polymorphisms have been discovered in CYP2C8, which metabolizes Taxol (paclitaxel). Genetic testing is available for all known CYP2C alleles.

abstract: Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying individuals most at risk of harm from certain drugs. Routine adoption of pharmaceutical tests requires evidence of their cost-effectiveness. The present review aims to systematically review published economic evaluations of drug tests aimed at preventing or reducing the occurrence of adverse drug reactions. We conducted a systematic literature review of economic evaluations of drug tests aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. The literature was searched using Embase, MEDLINE and the NHS Economic Evaluation Database with search terms relating to drug tests, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluations and pharmaceuticals. Titles were screened independently by two reviewers. Articles considered to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened for abstract and full texts. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met inclusion criteria. There was evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of testing for HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58:01 (before allopurinol) and CYP2C19. (Before treatment with clopidogrel). Economic evidence was inconclusive for TPMT (before treatment with 6-mercaptobutene, azathioprine, and cisplatin), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (for informing genotype-guided dosing of coumarin derivatives), MTHFR (before treatment with methotrexate), and Factor V Leiden testing (before treatment with methotrexate). For oral contraception). Testing for A1555G is not cost-effective before prescribing aminoglycosides. Our systematic review identified strong evidence for the cost-effectiveness of pre-treatment genotyping with a number of common drugs. However, further analyzes and/or strong clinical evidence are necessary to make recommendations to others.

abstract: This article summarizes the discussions of the third European Science Foundation-University of Barcelona (ESF-UB) Conference in Biomedicine on Pharmacogenetics and Pharmacogenomics, held in June 2010 in Spain. It focused on practical applications in routine medical practice. We provide practical recommendations for ten different clinical situations, both approved and unapproved by regulatory bodies. We suggest some notes that may accompany the results of these tests, which indicate the best medication and doses that should be prescribed. Examples discussed include KRAS, cetuximab, panitumumab, EGFR-gefitinib, CYP2D6-tamoxifen, TPMT-azathioprine-6-mercaptopurine, VKORC1/CYP2C9-warfarin, CYP2C19-clopidogrel, HLA-B*5701-abacavir, and HLA-B*5701. -. Flucloxacillin, SLCO1B1-statins and CYP3A5-tacrolimus. We hope that these practical recommendations will help clinicians, biologists, scientists, and other health care professionals describe, perform, and interpret these genetic tests.

abstract: During HIV infection and/or antiretroviral therapy (ART), monocytes and macrophages exhibit a wide range of dysfunctions that significantly contribute to HIV pathogenesis and treatment-related complications. However, the molecular components that contribute to these imbalances remain elusive. We therefore applied a parallel approach of genome-wide microarray analysis and focused gene expression profiling on monocytes from patients at different stages of HIV infection and/or ART to further characterize these dysfunctions. Processes involving apoptosis, cell cycle, lipid metabolism, proteasome function, protein trafficking and transcriptional regulation have been identified as areas of monocyte dysfunction during HIV infection. Individual genes potentially contributing to these monocyte imbalances included several novel factors. One of these is the adipocytokin NAMPT/visfatin, which we have shown is able to inhibit HIV at an early step in its life cycle. Approximately half of the identified genes were restored to control levels under ART, while the other genes represented persistent dysregulation. In addition, several candidate biomarkers (particularly CCL1 and CYP2C19) have been proposed for the development of abacavir hypersensitivity reaction. Previously described areas of monocyte dysfunction during HIV infection were confirmed, and new themes were identified. Furthermore, individual genes associated with these imbalances and disorders associated with ART have been identified. These genes form a useful basis for further functional studies regarding the contribution of monocytes/macrophages to HIV pathogenesis. One of these genes, NAMPT/visfatin, represents a potential new restriction factor for HIV.

abstract: Pharmacogenomic studies contribute to our understanding of interindividual differences in response to antiretroviral drugs. Genetic polymorphisms in histocompatibility complex genes predict the likelihood of hypersensitivity reactions in people prescribed abacavir, and possibly nevirapine. Recent studies have shown that polymorphisms in the CYP2B6 gene are associated with higher efavirenz plasma concentrations and increased CNS side effects. Polymorphisms in the MDR1 gene that encodes the drug pump, P-glycoprotein, may predict nevirapine-associated hepatotoxicity and long-term virological response to efavirenz. CYP2C19 polymorphisms predict nelfinavir plasma levels and possibly the risk of virologic failure on this drug. The European Mitochondrial Haplogroup may predict an increased risk of peripheral neuropathy associated with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors. Expanding and refining knowledge regarding associations between human genetics and response to antiretroviral drugs may eventually allow treatment to be personalized based on genotyping. This article summarizes a presentation on HIV therapeutics and pharmacogenomics given by David W. Haas, MD, at the International AIDS Society USA session in Atlanta in March 2005.

abstract: Many long-chain fatty acids (LCFA) are natural ligands for non-ruminant peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG), which, along with their adipogenic target genes, are upregulated in bovine mammary tissue during lactation. Thus, PPARG may represent an important control point in bovine milk lipid synthesis. We tested the expression of the adipogenic gene network via quantitative PCR for 19 genes in bovine mammary epithelial cells cultured with 16:0, 18:0, cis-9 18:1, trans-10 18:1, trans-10, cis-12 18: 2[t10c12 conjugated linoleic acid (CLA)], 20:5, ethanol (control), and the PPARG agonist rosiglitazone (ROSI). Triplicate cultures were maintained for 12 h with 50 mM ROSI or 100 mM LCFA. Combined responses between 16:0 and 18:0 relative to control included significantly greater expression of INSIG1 (+298%, +92%), AGPAT6 (+137%, +169%), FABP3 (+755%, +338%), and FABP4 (+171%, 157%). This was coupled with greater intracellular lipid droplet formation and mRNA for ACSS2, LPIN1, SCD and SREBF2 in response to 16:0, and greater DGAT1 and THRSP at 18:0. Trans-10 18:1 and t10c12 CLA reduced the expression of FASN (-60%, -31%), SCD (-100%, -357%), and SREBF1 (-49%, -189%). Moreover, t10c12 CLA upregulated the expression of ACSS2, FABP3, INSIG1, SREBF2 and THRSP. Expression of SREBF1 was lower with cis-9 18:1 (-140%) and 20:5 (-125%) compared to control. This latter LCFA also reduced the expression of SCD, SREBF2, and LPL. No effects of LCFA or ROSI on PPARG were observed, but ROSI upregulated (+39% to +269%) the expression of ACACA, FASN, LPIN1, AGPAT6, DGAT1, SREBF1, SREBF2, and INSIG1. Thus, these genes are putative PPARG target genes in bovine mammary cells. This is the first report demonstrating the direct effect of trans-10 18:1 on adipogenic gene expression of bovine mammary cells. Coordinated regulation of adipogenic gene networks in response to ROSI and saturating LCFA provides support for PPARG activation in the regulation of bovine milk lipid synthesis.

abstract: In adipose tissue, muscle, liver, and macrophages, signaling by the nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPAR-γ) is one of the determinants of insulin sensitivity and this receptor mediates the insulin-sensitizing effects of thiazolidinediones (TZDs). Because PPAR-γ is also expressed in neurons, we generated mice with neuron-specific Pparg knockout (brain Pparg knockout (BKO)) to determine whether neuronal PPAR-γ signaling contributes to weight gain or insulin sensitivity. During feeding with a high-fat diet (HFD), food intake was reduced and energy expenditure was increased in Pparg-BKO mice compared to Pparg(f/f) mice, resulting in reduced weight gain. Pparg-BKO mice also responded better to leptin administration compared to Pparg(f/f) mice. When treated with the TZD rosiglitazone, Pparg-BKO mice were resistant to rosiglitazone-induced hyperphagia and weight gain, and compared with rosiglitazone-treated Pparg(f/f) mice, only marginally improved glucose metabolism. Hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemic clamp studies showed that the increase in hepatic insulin sensitivity induced by rosiglitazone treatment during HFD feeding was completely abolished in Pparg-BKO mice, an effect associated with the failure of rosiglitazone to improve insulin receptor signal transduction in the liver. We conclude that weight gain induced by high-density feeding depends in part on the effect of neuronal PPAR-γ signaling to reduce thermogenesis and increase food intake. Neuronal PPAR-γ signaling is also required for the hepatic insulin-sensitizing effects of TZDs.

abstract: Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR gamma) is an important regulator of lipid and glucose homeostasis and cellular differentiation. Studies on many cell types in vitro and in vivo have demonstrated that activation of PPAR gamma can reduce cell proliferation. Here we show that activation of PPAR gamma is sufficient to reduce the proliferation of cultured insulinoma cell lines. We created a model with mice in which expression of the PPARG gene in beta cells was knocked out (beta gamma KO mice), and these mice were found to have significant islet hypertrophy on a chow diet. Interestingly, the normal expansion of beta cell mass that occurs in control mice in response to high-fat feeding is markedly impaired in these animals. Despite this change in beta cell mass, no effect on glucose homeostasis was observed in beta gamma KO mice. In addition, while thiazolidinediones enhanced insulin secretion from cultured wild-type islets, administration of rosiglitazone to insulin-resistant control and beta-gamma KO mice revealed that PPAR gamma in beta cells is not required for the antidiabetic actions of these compounds. These data demonstrate an important physiological role for PPAR gamma function in beta cell proliferation and also suggest that the mechanisms controlling beta cell hypertrophy in obesity differ from those regulating basic islet cell mass.

abstract: Nocturnin (NOC) is a circadian-regulated protein associated with the yeast family of transcription factors involved in cellular response to nutrient status. In mammals, NOC functions as a deadenylase but lacks a transcriptional activation domain. It is highly expressed in bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs), hepatocytes, and adipocytes. In BMSCs exposed to PPAR-gamma (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma) rosiglitazone, Noc expression was enhanced 30-fold. Previously, we reported that Noc(−/−) mice had low body temperature, were protected from diet-induced obesity, and most importantly showed an absence of the circadian rhythm Pparg on a high-fat diet. Consistent with its role in influencing the allocation of BMSCs, Noc(-/-) mice have reduced bone marrow adiposity and higher bone mass. In the same context, overexpression of NOC promotes adipogenesis in 3T3-L1 cells but negatively regulates osteogenesis in MC3T3-E1 cells. NOC and the mutant form, which lacks deadenylase activity, bind to PPAR-gamma and markedly enhance PPAR-gamma transcriptional activity. Both WT and mutant NOC facilitate nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma. Importantly, NOC-mediated nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma is blocked by a short peptide fragment of NOC that prevents its physical interaction with PPAR-gamma. The inhibitory effect of this NOC peptide was partially reversed by rosiglitazone, suggesting that the effect of NOC on nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma may be independent of ligand-mediated PPAR-gamma activation. In summary, Noc plays a unique role in regulating mesenchymal stem cell lineage allocation by modulating PPAR-gamma activity through nuclear translocation. These data demonstrate a unique mechanism by which a nutrient-responsive gene affects BMSCs differentiation, adipogenesis, and ultimately body composition.

abstract: In this study we sought to test the hypothesis that genetic factors may influence antidepressant response to fluoxetine. The research focused on seven candidate genes in the serotonergic pathway involved in serotonin synthesis, transport, recognition and degradation. Our clinical sample consisted of 96 individuals with unipolar major depression treated with fluoxetine with response variables assessed after a 12-week trial. Patient data were also collected to investigate the pattern of response to medications. Using a high-throughput single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping platform and capillary electrophoresis, we genotyped patients at 110 SNPs and four repeat polymorphisms located in seven candidate genes (HTR1A, HTR2A, HTR2C, MAOA, SLC6A4, TPH1, and TPH2). Statistical tests performed included locus and haplotype linkage tests, and linkage disequilibrium (LD) estimation. Little evidence of population stratification was observed in the sample containing 20 random SNPs using the genomic control procedure. Our most interesting results included three SNPs in the TPH1 gene and one SNP in the SLC6A4 gene, which showed a significant association at a single locus when fluoxetine response was compared to nonresponse (P = 0.02-0.04). All odds ratios indicated an increased risk of non-response to fluoxetine. In the specific response versus indeterminate and nonresponse comparison, three SNPs in the TPH2 gene (P = 0.02-0.04) were positively associated and one SNP in the HTR2A gene (P = 0.02) was negatively associated. When comparing a specific response to a non-specific response, we found significant negative associations in three SNPs in the HTR2A gene (P = 0.001-0.03) and two SNPs in the MAOA gene (P = 0.03-0.05). We observed a variant, despite strong LD, in each gene and unexpectedly low numbers of estimated haplotypes, which consisted of tagged polymorphisms. Significant haplotype associations were found in all genes except HTR1A and HTR2C. Although these data should be interpreted with caution given the small sample size, these results suggest the involvement of TPH1 and SLC6A4 in the general response, and HTR2A, TPH2 and MAOA in the specificity of response to fluoxetine. Interestingly, we note that a number of less frequent alleles of several SNP markers were associated with non-responsive and indeterminate phenotypes.

abstract: The serotonin transporter is the molecular target of many antidepressants, and the gene (SLC6A4) that encodes this protein has been associated with response to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). We sought to test the hypothesis that SLC6A4 is associated with SSRI response by re-identifying this gene in subjects with major depression. All exons, portions of all introns, and the promoter region containing the polymorphic repeat polymorphism (HTTLPR) polymorphism previously associated with SSRI response were sequenced for 96 subjects, and variants were tested for association with response to treatment with fluoxetine. We screened a total of 712 kilobases of sequence and found 27 SLC6A4 variants, 21 of which had not been previously described. Seventeen were seen on one chromosome each, including three of the five exonic variants. A polymorphism (rs25531), upstream of the HTTLPR, showed evidence of an association with response to treatment, and biochemical experiments showed that this polymorphism alters the binding of nuclear extracts to a consensus sequence of activating protein transcription factor 2, which is thought to be a transcription factor. A critical factor in the regulation of neuronal gene expression in mammals. These results support an association between response to SSRIs and deoxyribonucleic acid variation at the serotonin transporter locus. We have also identified an important functional variant potentially contributing to this association and a potential biological mechanism that could mediate its effect.

abstract: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by repetitive, intrusive, disturbing thoughts (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors or mental actions that a person feels driven to do (compulsions). OCD has a partly genetic basis. To treat OCD, strong serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SRI) medications (clomipramine (Anafranil), fluvoxamine (Luvox), fluoxetine (Prozac), sertraline (Zoloft), and paroxetine (Paxil)) are used, which act on the serotonin transport protein. Uniquely effective. A polymorphism in the promoter region of the gene (SLC6A4) encoding this protein has recently been reported to affect protein expression and be associated with measures of anxiety, depression, and autism (using a family-controlled transmission disequilibrium test (TDT) design). . SLC6A4 thus has strong prior support for a potential impact on OCD risk: the protein it encodes is a drug target; Polymorphisms in the gene affect function; Polymorphisms have been shown to be associated with behavioral patterns. We used TDT with a cohort of 34 European-American triplet families, 30 unrelated and four derived from extended pedigrees, to test for linkage disequilibrium between OCD and alleles at a polymorphic locus of the SLC6A4 promoter. Of the 35 heterozygous parents, 24 transmitted the SLC6A4 'l' allele and 11 transmitted the 's' allele (chi 2 TDT = 4.83; P < 0.03). Considering only the 13 SRI non-responders, there were 13 heterozygous parents, of whom 10 carried the 'l' allele and three the 's' allele (chi 2 TDT = 3.77; P < 0.052). These data provide preliminary support for linkage disequilibrium and association between the SLC6A4 'l' allele and OCD.

abstract: Recent major findings from studies of SLC6A4 and its counterpart protein, serotonin (5-HT) transporter (SERT) in humans, rodents and non-human primates indicate that combinations of SLC6A4 non-coding 5', 3' UTRs and intronic regions as well as coding variants that act together can Altered 5HT transport by up to 40-fold in vitro. In vivo, SLC6A4 variants in humans and other species lead to marked physiological changes, despite attenuation of neurodevelopmental adaptations in 5-HT receptors as well as compensatory alterations in 5-HT synthesis and metabolism. Polymorphisms in SLC6A4 are associated with differences in emotional, endocrine, and personality characteristics as well as several diseases. This gene, in combinations with gene × gene (G × G) and gene × environment (G × E) interactions, is still not fully understood, with some association results remaining controversial. Given their fundamental importance in the regulation and function of the entire serotonergic system (as demonstrated by the consequences of inhibition of SERT reuptake by SSRIs such as fluoxetine in humans and transgenic changes in mice and rats), it seems likely that SLC6A4 and SERT will remain areas of great interest in attempts to Our field is to better understand and treat 5-HT related disorders.

abstract: Abacavir hypersensitivity reaction is strongly associated with the presence of the HLA-B*5701 allele. This study was designed to determine the potential effectiveness of screening for HLA-B*5701 to prevent hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. This randomized, double-blind study included 1,956 patients from 19 countries who were infected with HIV type 1 and who had not previously received abacavir. We randomly assigned patients to undergo prospective HLA-B*5701 screening, excluding HLA-B*5701-positive patients from abacavir treatment (prospective screening group), or to undergo the standard-of-care approach to abacavir without potential HLA-B*5701 screening (prospective screening group). Controller). All patients started on abacavir were observed for 6 weeks. To immunologically confirm and enhance the specificity of the clinical diagnosis of hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir, we performed an epicutaneous patch test with abacavir. The prevalence of HLA-B*5701 was 5.6% (109 of 1956 patients). Among patients receiving abacavir, 72% were men, 84% were white, and 18% had never received antiretroviral therapy. Screening eliminated immunologically confirmed hypersensitivity reaction (0% in the potential screening group vs. 2.7% in the control group, P<0.001), with a negative predictive value of 100% and a positive predictive value of 47.9%. Hypersensitivity reaction was clinically diagnosed in 93 patients, with a significantly lower incidence in the potential screening group (3.4%) compared with the control group (7.8%) (P < 0.001). HLA-B*5701 testing reduces the risk of hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. In predominantly white populations, similar to those in this study, 94% of patients do not carry the HLA-B*5701 allele and are at low risk for a hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. Our results show that pharmacogenetic testing can be used to prevent a specific toxic effect of a drug. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00340080.)

abstract: The use of abacavir - a potent inhibitor of HIV-1 nucleoside reverse transcriptase - is complicated by a potentially life-threatening hypersensitivity syndrome in approximately 5% of cases. Genetic factors that influence the immune response to abacavir may confer susceptibility. We aimed to find associations between MHC alleles and abacavir hypersensitivity in HIV-1-infected individuals treated with abacavir. MHC region typing was performed in the first 200 participants in a Western Australian HIV cohort study exposed to abacavir. Significant hypersensitivity to abacavir was identified in 18 cases and was ruled out in 167 individuals exposed to the drug for more than 6 weeks (abacavir tolerant). 15 people had some symptoms but did not meet the criteria for abacavir hypersensitivity. p values ​​were corrected for comparisons between multiple HLA alleles (p(c)) by multiplying the raw p value by the estimated number of HLA alleles present within the locus examined. HLA-B*5701 was present in 14 (78%) of 18 patients with abacavir hypersensitivity, and in four (2%) of 167 abacavir-tolerant patients (OR 117 [95% CI 29-481], p(c (<0.0001), and the combination of HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 was found in 13 (72%) of hypersensitive and five (3%) of tolerant patients (73 [20-268], p(c)<0.0001). HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 were combined in 13 (72%) of the hypersensitive patients and none of the tolerant patients (822 [43-15675], p(c)<0.0001) Other MHC markers also present on the ancestral haplotype 57.1 to which the above three markers belong confirmed the presence of the haplotype-specific linkage defect, and mapped potential susceptibility loci to a region bounded by C4A6 and HLA-C within the entire abacavir-exposed group (n=200). Because HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 have a positive predictive value for hypersensitivity of 100%, and a negative predictive value of 97%, genetic susceptibility to abacavir hypersensitivity is determined by the ancestral haplotype 57.1 in our population, withholding abacavir in... Patients with HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 reduced the prevalence of hypersensitivity from 9% to 2.5% without depriving any patients of inappropriate use of abacavir.

abstract: Hypersensitivity to abacavir affects about 4% of patients receiving the drug for treatment of HIV-1 infection. We performed a retrospective case-control study to identify multiple peri-HLA-B markers associated with hypersensitivity reactions. HLA-B57 was present in 39 (46%) of 84 patients versus four (4%) of 113 controls (P < 0 small median point 0001). However, because of the lower numbers of women and other ethnic groups enrolled, these results largely relate to white men. The lower sensitivity of HLA-B57 for predicting abacavir hypersensitivity identified in this study compared to a previous report highlights that the predictive values ​​of markers will vary between populations. Clinical monitoring and management of hypersensitivity reactions in patients receiving abacavir should remain unchanged.

abstract: Human leukocyte antigens (HLAs) are highly polymorphic proteins that initiate immunity by presenting pathogen-derived peptides to T cells. HLA polymorphisms predominantly map to the antigen-binding cleft, thus diversifying the repertoire of self- and pathogen-derived peptide antigens selected by different HLA allotypes. An increasing number of immune-based drug reactions, including abacavir hypersensitivity syndrome (AHS) and carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), are associated with specific HLA alleles. However, little is known about the underlying mechanisms of these associations, including AHS, a typical HLA-linked drug reaction that occurs exclusively in individuals with the common histocompatibility allele HLA-B*57:01, and with a relative risk greater than 1,000. (Refs 6, 7). We have shown that unmodified abacavir binds non-covalently to HLA-B*57:01, lying across the bottom of the antigen-binding cleft and into the F pocket, where the carboxy-terminal tryptophan normally stabilizes HLA-B*57:01-binding peptides. . Abacavir binds with remarkable specificity to HLA-B*57:01, altering the conformation and chemistry of the antigen-binding cleft, thereby altering the repertoire of endogenous peptides that can bind HLA-B*57:01. In this way, abacavir directs the selection of new endogenous peptides, leading to a marked change in the “immune self.” The peptide-centered “variable self” activates abacavir-specific T cells, leading to polyclonal CD8 T cell activation and systemic reaction manifested as AHS. We also show that carbamazepine, a widely used antiepileptic drug associated with hypersensitivity reactions in HLA-B*15:02 individuals, binds to this variant, resulting in changes in the repertoire of presented endogenous peptides. Our findings simultaneously highlight the importance of HLA polymorphisms in evolving pharmacogenomics and provide a general mechanism for some of the increasing number of HLA-associated hypersensitivities involving small molecule drugs.

abstract: Progress in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, especially with regard to tyrosine kinase inhibitors, requires regular updating of concepts and management. A European LeukemiaNet expert panel reviewed previous and new studies to update recommendations made in 2009. We recommend imatinib, nilotinib, or dasatinib as first-line treatment. Response is assessed using real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction and/or cytogenetics at 3, 6, and 12 months. BCR-ABL1 transcript levels ≥10% at 3 months, <1% at 6 months, and ≥0.1% from 12 months onwards define optimal response, while >10% at 6 months and >1% at 12 months onwards define Failure, and this requires a change in treatment. Likewise, partial cytogenetic response (PCyR) at 3 months and complete cytogenetic response (CCyR) from 6 months onward define optimal response, whereas no CyR (Philadelphia chromosome positive [Ph+] > 95%) at 3 months, less PCyR at 6 months, and less than CCyR from 12 months onwards define failure. Between optimum and failure, there is an intermediate warning zone that requires more frequent monitoring. Similar definitions are provided for response to second-line treatment. Specific recommendations are made for patients with advanced stages and tumors, and for allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Optimal responders should continue treatment indefinitely, with close monitoring, or may be enrolled in controlled studies to discontinue treatment once a deeper molecular response has been achieved.

abstract: Although the role of Hedgehog (Hh) signaling in embryogenesis is well established, its functions in adult tissue regeneration and maintenance remain unclear, and the relationship of these functions to cancer development has not been determined. Here we show that loss of Smooth (Smo), an essential component of the Hh pathway, impairs hematopoietic stem cell regeneration and reduces induction of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) by the BCR-ABL1 oncoprotein. Loss of Smo depletes CML stem cells—the cells that spread leukemia—while constitutively active Smo increases the number of CML stem cells and accelerates the disease. As a potential mechanism of Smo action, we show that the cell fate determinant Numb, which depletes CML stem cells, is increased in the absence of Smo activity. Moreover, pharmacological inhibition of Hh signaling attenuates not only the proliferation of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) driven by wild-type BCR-ABL1, but also the growth of imatinib-resistant mice and human CML. These data indicate that Hh pathway activity is required for maintenance of normal and tumorigenic stem cells in the hematopoietic system and raise the possibility that drug resistance and disease recurrence associated with imatinib treatment of CML can be avoided by targeting this essential stem cell maintenance pathway.

abstract: There is significant variation in the level of molecular responses achieved with imatinib therapy in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). These differences could result from variable treatment adherence. Eighty-seven patients with chronic myeloid leukemia in chronic phase treated with imatinib 400 mg/day for a median of 59.7 months (range, 25–104 months) and who achieved a complete cytogenetic response had adherence monitored over a 3-month period using electronic micromonitoring. device. Adherence was associated with levels of molecular response. Other factors that could influence the outcome were also analysed. The median adherence rate was 98% (range, 24% to 104%). Twenty-three patients (26.4%) had adherence < or = 90%; In 12 of these patients (14%), adherence was <or=80%. There was a strong association between adherence rate (< or = 90% or > 90%) and the 6-year probability of a 3-log reduction (also known as major molecular response [MMR]) in BCR-ABL1 transcripts (28.4%) v 94.5%; P < .001) and also complete molecular response (CMR; 0% v 43.8%; P = .002). Multivariate analysis identified adherence (relative risk [RR], 11.7; P = .001) and expression of human molecular organic cation transporter-1 (RR, 1.79; P = .038) as the only independent predictors of MMR. Adherence was the only independent predictor of CMR. No molecular responses were observed when adherence was < or = 80% ( P < .001). Patients whose imatinib doses were increased had poor adherence (86.4%). In this latter population, adherence was the only independent predictor of inability to achieve MMR (RR, 17.66; P = .006). In patients with chronic myeloid leukemia who have been treated with imatinib for several years, poor adherence may be the predominant reason for the inability to obtain adequate molecular responses.

abstract: Imatinib, a selective BCR-ABL1 kinase inhibitor, has improved the prognosis of patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). We performed efficacy and safety analyzes based on more than 10 years of follow-up in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia who were treated with imatinib as first-line therapy. In this open-label, multicenter, cross-over design trial, we randomly assigned patients with newly diagnosed chronic myeloid leukemia in the chronic phase to receive either imatinib or interferon alfa plus cytarabine. Long-term analyzes included overall survival, response to treatment, and serious adverse events. The average follow-up was 10.9 years. Given the high crossover rate among patients randomly assigned to receive interferon alfa plus cytarabine (65.6%) and the short duration of treatment before crossover in these patients (median, 0.8 years), the present analyzes focused on patients who received repeat therapy. They were randomly assigned to receive imatinib. Among patients in the imatinib group, the estimated overall survival rate at 10 years was 83.3%. Nearly half of the patients (48.3%) randomly assigned to imatinib completed study treatment with imatinib, and 82.8% had a complete cytogenetic response. The serious adverse events that researchers considered to be related to imatinib were uncommon and occurred most often during the first year of treatment. Approximately 11 years of follow-up showed that the effectiveness of imatinib was maintained over time and that long-term administration of imatinib was not associated with unacceptable cumulative or late toxic effects. (Funded by Novartis Pharmaceuticals; IRIS ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00006343 and NCT00333840.).

abstract: The HER2 gene, which encodes the growth factor receptor HER2, is amplified, and HER2 is overexpressed in 25 to 30 percent of breast cancers, increasing tumor aggressiveness. We evaluated the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab, a recombinant monoclonal antibody against HER2, in women with metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We randomly assigned 234 patients to receive standard chemotherapy alone and 235 patients to receive standard chemotherapy plus trastuzumab. Patients who had not previously received adjuvant (postoperative) treatment with anthracyclines were treated with doxorubicin (or epirubicin in 36 women), cyclophosphamide alone (138 women) or trastuzumab (143 women). Patients who had previously received adjuvant anthracyclines were treated with paclitaxel alone (96 women) or paclitaxel with trastuzumab (92 women). The addition of trastuzumab to chemotherapy was associated with a longer time to disease progression (median, 7.4 vs. 4.6 months; P<0.001), a higher objective response rate (50% vs. 32%, P<0.001), and a longer response rate (50% vs. 32%; P <0.001). Duration of response (median, 9.1 vs. 6.1 months; P<0.001), lower death rate at 1 year (22% vs. 33%; P=0.008), and longer survival (median survival, 25.1 vs. 20.3 months); P = 0.01), a 20 percent reduction in the risk of death. The most significant adverse event was New York Heart Association grade 3 or 4 cardiac dysfunction, which occurred in 27 percent of the group given anthracyclines, cyclophosphamide, and trastuzumab. 8% of the group were given anthracyclines and cyclophosphamide alone; 13% of the group were given paclitaxel and trastuzumab. 1% of the group was given paclitaxel alone. Although cardiotoxicity was potentially severe and, in some cases, life-threatening, symptoms generally improved with standard medical management. Trastuzumab increases the clinical benefit of first-line chemotherapy in HER2-overexpressing metastatic breast cancer.

abstract: Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2; also known as ERBB2), has been studied in combination with chemotherapy for the first-line treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. ToGA (trastuzumab for gastric cancer) was an international, open-label, phase III, randomized controlled trial conducted at 122 centers in 24 countries. Patients with gastroesophageal or gastroesophageal junction carcinoma were eligible for inclusion if their tumors showed increased expression of HER2 protein by immunohistochemistry or gene amplification by in situ hybridization. Participants were randomly assigned 1:1 to receive a chemotherapy regimen consisting of capecitabine plus cisplatin, fluorouracil plus cisplatin given every 3 weeks for six cycles, or chemotherapy in combination with intravenous trastuzumab. Allocation was by randomization stratified by Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, chemotherapy regimen, extent of disease, site of primary cancer, and measurability of disease, which was implemented using a central interactive voice recognition system. The primary endpoint was overall survival in all randomized patients who received the study drug at least once. This trial is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01041404. 594 patients were randomly assigned to study treatment (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, n = 298; chemotherapy alone, n = 296), of whom 584 were included in the primary analysis (n = 294; n = 290). Median follow-up was 18.6 months (IQR 11-25) in the trastuzumab plus chemotherapy group and 17.1 months (9-25) in the chemotherapy alone group. Median overall survival was 13.8 months (95% CI 12-16) in those assigned to trastuzumab plus chemotherapy compared with 11.1 months (10-13) in those assigned to chemotherapy alone (hazard ratio 0.74; 95% CI 0.60). 0.91; p=0.0046). The most common adverse events in both groups were nausea (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, 197 [67%] versus chemotherapy alone, 184 [63%]), vomiting (147 [50%] versus 134 [46%]), and Neutrophils (157). [53%] versus 165 [57%]). Rates of overall grade 3 or 4 adverse events (201 [68%] vs. 198 [68%]) and cardiac adverse events (17 [6%] vs. 18 [6%]) did not differ between groups. Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy may be considered a new standard option for patients with HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. F. Hoffmann-La Roche.

abstract: We present the pooled results of two trials that compared adjuvant chemotherapy with or without concurrent trastuzumab in women with surgically removed HER2-positive breast cancer. The National Adjuvant Surgical Breast and Bowel Project B-31 trial compared doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by paclitaxel every 3 weeks (Group 1) with the same regimen plus 52 weeks of trastuzumab starting at the first dose of paclitaxel (Group 2). The North Central Cancer Treatment Group trial N9831 compared three regimens: doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by weekly paclitaxel (Group A), the same regimen followed by 52 weeks of trastuzumab after paclitaxel (Group B), and the same regimen plus 52 weeks of trastuzumab initiated. In combination with paclitaxel (Group C). The studies were modified to include a combined analysis comparing groups 1 and A (control group) with groups 2 and C (trastuzumab group). Group B was excluded because trastuzumab was not administered concomitantly with paclitaxel. By 15 March 2005, 394 cases (recurrence, second primary cancer, or death before recurrence) had been reported, leading to the first scheduled interim analysis. Of these, 133 were in the trastuzumab group and 261 were in the control group (hazard ratio 0.48; P<0.0001). This result exceeded the limits of early stopping. The absolute difference in disease-free survival between the trastuzumab group and the control group was 12 percent after three years. Treatment with trastuzumab was associated with a 33% reduction in the risk of death (P=0.015). The three-year cumulative incidence of grade 3 or 4 congestive heart failure or death from cardiac causes in the trastuzumab group was 4.1 percent in trial B-31 and 2.9 percent in trial N9831. Trastuzumab combined with paclitaxel after doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide improves outcomes among women with surgically resected HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00004067 and NCT00005970.)

abstract: Trastuzumab, a recombinant monoclonal antibody against HER2, has clinical activity in advanced breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We investigated its efficacy and safety after resection of early-stage breast cancer and completion of chemotherapy. This international, multicenter, randomized trial compared one or two years of trastuzumab given every three weeks with observational patients with HER2-positive, node-negative, or node-positive breast cancer who completed regional brachytherapy and at least four cycles of neoadjuvant or node-specific adjuvant. Adjuvant chemotherapy. Data were available for 1,694 women randomly assigned to 2 years of trastuzumab, 1,694 women assigned to 1 year of trastuzumab, and 1,693 women assigned to observation. We report here the results of only 1-year trastuzumab treatment or observation. In the first planned interim analysis (median follow-up of 1 year), 347 events (breast cancer recurrence, contralateral breast cancer, second non-breast malignancy, or death) were observed: 127 events in the trastuzumab group and 220 events in Note. group. The unadjusted hazard ratio of an event in the trastuzumab group, compared with the control group, was 0.54 (95 percent confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.67; P < 0.0001 by log-rank test, crossing interim limits of analysis), representing the absolute benefit in terms of survival. Disease-free life for two years increased by 8.4 percentage points. Overall survival in the two groups was not significantly different (29 deaths with trastuzumab versus 37 with observation). Severe cardiotoxicity developed in 0.5 percent of women treated with trastuzumab. One year of treatment with trastuzumab after adjuvant chemotherapy significantly improves disease-free survival among women with HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00045032.)
